These roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold right now, so I’ll be warm in the car," he said. Alistair was also eager, dressed in full winter cycling gear, unlike Jonny who wore jeans and a sweatshirt. Alistair joked, "I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’ll even make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up."

The race began at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and was to end at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, which is 350 meters up. This might not be a problem for the car, but Alistair had a tough start with a steep 25% incline. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair sped away on his bike, heading straight up the hill and across the countryside to Fleet Moss, while Jonny got into the car and hit the road. They would only see each other again at the finish line. The question was, who would get there first?

Jonny’s confidence was quickly challenged. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he encountered a giant tractor blocking the road. "Welcome to Yorkshire," he joked to the cameraman in his car. "If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!" After dealing with the tractor, Jonny was back on track, driving into the morning mist.

Meanwhile, Alistair struggled with the steep slope. Just a couple of miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched curiously as the Olympic champion kept a steady pace, carrying his bike. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side was open ground, and with the sun shining, he had a chance to show his skills. He picked up speed, head down and feet on the pedals.

In the car, Jonny faced another challenge. The roads in this part of Yorkshire are very old and not built for speed. He had to carefully navigate narrow corners and drive through a stream on the road. Once past the last village, he raced straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped towards Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the opposite side. 

With his head down and legs pumping, Alistair reached the line and stopped. He looked up and asked the crowd, "Is he here?" When they said no, he raised his arms in victory. Minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car. "Well done," Jonny said, clearly disappointed. "I’m gutted."

Playing on Centre Court at Wimbledon is a unique experience because of the silence. When you bounce the ball on the soft grass, you hear the echo of your shots. The well-kept grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds create a special atmosphere that feels separate from the outside world. This quiet helps me focus on my game. During a match, I try to block out everything except the game and the point I'm playing. The silence is only broken by applause and cheers when a point is won. Even though there are 15,000 people watching, I feel distant from them. I am so focused that I forget millions are watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final, the biggest match of my life.

I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach forever, taught me that Wimbledon is the most important tournament. By age 14, I was telling my friends that I would play there and win. Before 2008, I had played and lost twice to Federer, including in the final the year before. Losing in 2006 wasn't too hard because I was just happy to be there at age 20. Federer beat me easily because I didn't believe in myself enough. But losing in 2007 was devastating. I knew I could have played better, and it was my mindset that let me down. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing is always painful, but it's worse when you know you had a chance. My uncle Toni, who is usually very tough on me, tried to comfort me, saying there would be more chances. I told him he didn't understand, thinking it was my last chance to win. I know a professional athlete's career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important than others, and I felt I missed a big one in 2007. Toni couldn't ease my sadness, but he was right. I got another chance in 2008, just a year later. I was confident I had learned from my defeat and that my mindset was strong. The night before the final, at dinner with family and friends, we didn't talk about the match. They knew I was already mentally preparing for it, and I needed that space to be mine alone until the match started.

In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. In one of her first letters home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood." Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society helped make her famous by producing articles and TV documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including award-winning children's books and the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages.

Jane Goodall is possibly the most celebrated female scientist of the 20th century, alongside Marie Curie. However, her fame might have overshadowed her real achievements. Many articles and books about her life often focus on her adventurous spirit or her role as a feminist, which can undervalue her work. Based on the number of academic references to her research, the success of her students, and the data from her 40-year study, Jane Goodall should be seen as a leading pioneer in her field and a top zoologist. Her main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees.

Before Goodall's work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew they ate meat or used tools, and we didn't realize they shared emotions and social systems similar to humans. We also didn't know that chimpanzee communities have different cultural traditions. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe" (1986), is a key work in chimpanzee research. Her long-term study in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements by biologist Stephen Jay Gould. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves, as chimpanzees are our closest relatives.

Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future career. At five years old, in the autumn of 1939, she disappeared one afternoon. The police and neighbors searched for her, and she reappeared with straw in her hair. She explained to her mother that she had hidden in a henhouse for five hours to see how hens lay eggs. This curiosity can be seen as the start of her career as a biologist.

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford speaks to me using the voice of a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV and cartoons, and to those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. "I’ve just done a voiceover about back injuries," she says, "so I had to quickly learn how to pronounce many medical terms."

Shirley talks about what it takes to do voiceovers. "Many actors, even very famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many of them probably can," she says. "But there’s more to it than that. You have to bring the script to life for an audience who can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for publicity, but often they don’t get the parts because they’re used to acting with their whole bodies."

After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning a typical acting career. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV ads. "One day," she says, "the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly—I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits—but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a major part." Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. "Things just happened for me," she says. "In my second film, I was lucky enough to play the main character—and her brother and mother."

Adult female actors often provide voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors', and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and lots of paperwork, which production companies on tight schedules prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV.

Cartoons are the highlight of a job that includes everything from educational videos to vacuum cleaner ads. "Those are hard because you have to sound enthusiastic about something you don’t care about, but my years in this profession help," she says. "They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you're talking—that makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference."

The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel—a recording showing what the artist can do—is essential. "It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel," Shirley says. "There are agencies that specialize in helping voiceover artists put them together." She claims to have reached the top of her profession through persistence as much as natural talent. "Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or simply practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up."

For anyone considering a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending "specialist workshops—they cover all types of voiceover." She also believes a passion for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. "If I’ve been in the studio doing a particular kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards," she says. "My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices."

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a dream job for many kids, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually choose more practical careers, like becoming a tax lawyer or working in auto parts. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles, like those in school notebooks, seems unrealistic. Yet, some people do it. 

People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. In my case, I had a typical cartoonist's childhood: I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper looking for political cartoons on local issues. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was making enough money to support myself.

To become a cartoonist, you don't need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical skills needed are basic, but the job is still challenging. You shouldn't try to become a cartoonist unless you feel you can't do anything else. It's easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and leaves time for family and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I've done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I've also been a writer, caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don't turn down work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don't really want to do. It also helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of cartooning? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with newspapers and magazines, but those days are mostly over. Today, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to create and sell your work. Cartoonists with average talent but good business skills often do better than artistic geniuses who lack those skills.

I'm surprised by how many people worry about their ideas being stolen, even if they've never sold a cartoon. Some are so afraid that they won't show their work to anyone. Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a 'c' for 'copyright,' circle it, and write your name and the date. But realistically, it's more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it goes viral online, it might actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and decided to get rid of some things. One of those things was an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black, Japanese-made guitar. Normally, I hate throwing things away, so why did I want to get rid of this guitar? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to throw it away when a young man approached me, looking confused. He asked, "Are you really going to throw that away?" I said yes, already feeling a bit of regret. He asked if he could have it, and I agreed. We went our separate ways, but I felt a deep regret for years afterward.

Then, a few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later inside a fish. The email was from a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He told me, "I have your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold several times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back and used it to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell the guitar back to me. I was so emotional and would have paid any price, but Keith's price was fair. I had forgotten that my dad used to put name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have found this whole situation amusing.

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar in the 1970s when it was very popular. I loved its calming sound, but I struggled to make progress. So, I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn't need to be a great musician to be a rock star. When I took the guitar out of the box Keith sent me, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt smooth and dense, but smaller than I remembered. I felt the urge to stand up and play it with a strap over my shoulder. My fingers remembered the chords, even though I couldn't draw them. My fingertips felt the familiar pain of pressing the strings to play a chord.

The electric guitar is not really a solo instrument, so now that I'm learning it again, I might need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or perhaps there are others my age with similar experiences. We could call ourselves "The Regainers"!

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," about people who struggle with sleeplessness, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and moods. Insomniacs, whom I interviewed many of, will tell you that sleep is crucial for our mental, physical, and social well-being. Those who struggle to sleep often understand its importance the most. It's good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. But what about dreams? They haven't been discussed much. We often lose dreams, especially when we wake up early and miss the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM or 'Rapid Eye Movement' sleep, the stage rich in dreams. Our most vivid and emotionally powerful dreams happen during REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM, so someone who lives 90 years will spend six or seven years in REM. When people are deprived of REM, they experience more intense REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This suggests dreams have a purpose. When REM was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that interpreting dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research did not support this idea, and the study of dreams shifted to their physical origins. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, says Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use dreams better than others. He concluded that dream use increases with interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Don't teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? Stickgold says dreams help us combine things in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new connections. Dreams might help us see new patterns and create combinations that break our usual thinking habits. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They 'ignore the obvious and put together things that make unexpected sense ... This is what creativity is,' says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, even one you barely remember, seems to provide fluency and fuel for thought. On those days, words and images come so quickly that my fingers can barely keep up. I don't know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world. We all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly as we interact with colleagues, co-workers, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England. In her studio, which has a stunning sea view, you see empty frames on the walls alongside photos of her two daughters. Susie is a leading figure in the copyist art movement, known for her ability to recreate the richness of early 20th-century impressionist paintings and the brilliance of 16th-century Caravaggio portraits. Surprisingly, she doesn't keep any of her own work. "As soon as I finish them, they go," she says. Susie is in high demand. Over her 30-year career as a copyist artist, she has painted works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that even art experts can mistake them for the originals. While the originals sell for millions, her copies sell for between a few hundred pounds and £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them. Susie keeps her clients' names private, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors are true art lovers, but for others, status is important. One celebrity likes to show off his 'Van Gogh' painting, which is actually a 'Susie Ray Van Gogh.' "Many famous people pass off my copies as originals," she says. "That's their choice." Some collectors save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank and displaying Susie's copy. Susie is honest about her work. She makes her reproductions look as authentic as possible, believing that doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. She signs her name on the back of the canvas. Passing off a copy as an original is illegal, and although she knows people who have done it, she has never been tempted. People who make fakes often get into trouble. Susie isn't wealthy and has faced challenges, but her situation is more stable now, and risking her reputation doesn't make sense. Susie wasn't always a copyist. After her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. It was good training for her current work and sparked her interest in plants, but it was hard to live on. She had to be very precise and get things right the first time. She has no regrets but is glad she found something more financially rewarding. When young artists ask for advice, Susie emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights how much she has studied to achieve her skills. Her training allows her to do anything from drawing plants to copying 15th-century masterpieces to reproducing 20th-century abstract art. She now focuses on French impressionists, with Manet, Cezanne, and Degas as her favorites. Susie notes that people often think modern art is easy, almost like child's play. Impressionists painted quickly and freely, but they were also very detailed, which is a challenging combination. Given her talent, it's surprising that Susie doesn't create her own original art. Isn't art about self-expression? And could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She says her work is the result of years of training and dedication, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried creating her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—good, but not exceptional. Susie is a perfectionist.

During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur was deeply passionate about the sea and being the fastest sailor. From a young age, she was obsessed with sailing. She felt a strong connection with the boats she sailed around the world, working in perfect harmony with them. When she returned to land, everyday life seemed unimportant, and she quickly longed to be back at sea, challenging herself against nature, even in dangerous places.

After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop race around the world, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was a small, cramped space where she lived and worked for 94 days. She explained how she meticulously planned everything, down to the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she needed. Preparation was crucial, she said. She proudly displayed her stock of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. Her attention to detail in maintaining the boat was as impressive as her sailing skills. The boat was her entire world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey. Seeing abandoned whaling stations made her realize how humans take resources and move on without thinking. 

When I met Ellen at her office, she had just finished a passionate conference call. She explained why it's urgent to act now to save the planet. "No one is making more coal, oil, or gas. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find ways to stop using them up," she said. Initially, her message was about using less, but she later focused on reusing, like promoting reusable industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, Ellen has visited factories, mines, and power stations, speaking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. "I will never be an expert," she said, "but I love learning. The current situation is something I can't ignore. Compared to this, sailing seems selfish. This is about finding how my voice can be most helpful. It really matters."

Ellen also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and education to inspire young people to rethink and redesign a sustainable future. "I do miss the adventure of being at sea," she said. "It defines who I am. At sea, you are connected to everything around you, focused on records, practicalities, and survival. My new message isn't as simple as saying, 'I want to be the fastest around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this mission is more important than anything I've done before."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous among teenagers. He hopes to encourage kids to be more active, as many spend a lot of time on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' Climbing Everest is just one part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, the highest peaks on each continent. Not many people do this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these peaks and might complete them before he turns 20.

I talked to some experienced Everest climbers, and none of them thought it was a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the world's highest mountain. They agreed that a young climber might be physically strong enough, but they were unsure if a teenager would be emotionally ready. They also doubted if a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions during such a climb. The Romeros have heard these concerns before. Paul says, 'I know people criticize us, but I can't focus on that – there's still a lot to do. Karen and I think about the risks all the time, but we trust our experience as climbers. Watching Jordan grow stronger gives me confidence.'

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it just his father's ambition? Paul insists, 'This isn't about me wanting fame through my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later in life, but we decided, why not now? We regularly check with him to make sure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on achieving my goal.'

In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting challenge. The more daring the record, the more interest it gets. This creates a challenge for Jordan. People might say that focusing on records takes away from the enjoyment, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to engage with the media. This means blogging, doing photo shoots, and giving interviews. He needs to offer something impressive, like climbing Everest. Paul adds, 'If Jordan decides tomorrow that he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we'll end this project and head to the gym.'

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's likely they aren't listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won't know who he is. I'm studying music at university, but even my classmates don't know much about classical music. If you don't know the composers, you probably don't own their music. This is bad news for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells just 300 copies. I find that surprising. So, why is interest in classical music declining, even though it's been around for centuries? Older people often blame TV and video games, but I don't think that's the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn't attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who love classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I'm not a big classical music fan. I like many music styles, but my classical music collection is probably around that 3% mark. Why don't teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm, with many mood changes, are difficult for us. We like things fast. Experts say we struggle to focus for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop songs also have lyrics that appeal more to teenagers than long classical pieces without words. The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families played music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online, but we rarely choose classical. When was the last time you heard classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says more people are going to classical concerts now, but I doubt many are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in different places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don't know why people like classical music more as they get older, but if your parents love something, you might avoid it. Some blame schools for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids are excited to play it in school orchestras. They practice early and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy playing classical music, but it's not their first choice for listening. When we relax, we usually choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you regret that I’m here," she said to the school, smiling. Her mother was getting out of the car too and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie wouldn’t have minded if she had. Her mother already knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was an unusual school, with buildings hidden among trees on a wooded hillside; it seemed confusing at first. Then she noticed the signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," Bonnie said, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," her mother replied. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved between trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of trailing behind like a dog," Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be kicked out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not get it over with?" She left the building and headed for the riding centre, following the sign. There was a nice old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, she could see that right away. Almost every stall had a horse, and she walked along, looking at each one carefully. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, running her finger along its nose. The next horse caught her attention. "Aren’t you the best of them all!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. Probably lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," Bonnie said, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…" His name was Maverick. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle for you. They must be nearby." The room with the riding equipment was unlocked, to Bonnie’s delight. Focused on putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat high on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in charge of everything she could see. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I’m serious because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else." She nudged him into a walk, then a trot. "If I stay here, I think we could be great friends," she confided. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, a breeze brushing her cheek and making it glow. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he’d jump well.

I’ve met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. Cody is a 15-year-old Australian who has already released several successful songs. How did a relaxed surfer end up performing in front of thousands of fans? Cody explains, "I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven." He remembers that he was also swimming and surfing every day, which were more important to him at the time. At 13, while attending high school, he posted a few videos online. These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, asking for more videos. Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share them. The response was overwhelming. Cody was also a talented swimmer, training with top coaches and focusing on his sport. But then record labels showed interest, and he faced a tough decision: stay in Australia and continue swimming or take a risk by signing a record deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the risk. "It was very difficult for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career," he says. "Can you imagine, at 12 or 13, trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?" He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. "It was a big surprise to most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid," he recalls. "I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to be that way in this crazy world." So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family halfway around the world, giving up one dream to pursue another. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn’t directly involved in his career, they support him from the background. Cody believes it’s important to have a close group of supportive people around you to stay grounded. Of course, everyone has moments of doubt. "Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight and travels the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a regular life," Cody admits. "I worry about that sometimes, but my family always reassures me that they’re here to support and encourage me." Success in any career comes from being willing to say "yes" to opportunities, even when they’re scary. "It all happened so fast and unexpectedly," Cody says. "Now, to be visiting countries I never thought I’d see and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s like a dream many people have. But I know it won’t last forever."

I jumped out of bed, pulled back the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbag wall, which was there to stop the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting those sandbags into place. Last week, I worked long hours with most of the town's adults, showing I could handle it. But my grandfather didn't seem to notice. With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of steaming black water from the wood factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on both sides, and solid ice downstream. As I changed out of my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn't recognize him. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain—a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. It's more special to me than having a famous grandfather because only he, my mom, and I know about it. Plus, I have his diary from that trip, which I read before bed. I patted the chain and headed to the kitchen. "Morning, Rex," Mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. "You're up early for a Saturday. I'll make brunch after your training. Be careful." "Thanks, Mom." I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa as he came out of his room. "Watch where you're going!" he shouted. "Where are you off to?" "Sorry, Grandpa. I'm going kayaking." As if my wetsuit didn't make that clear. As if he didn't see me kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore his temper, but it's getting harder. "Why train? You didn't win the competition," he said. His words stung, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He went into the bathroom and slammed the door. Mom gave me a sympathetic smile. "Don't mind him. He's..." "...not himself right now," I finished for her. I didn't say he's always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a kid, he was my hero, especially when he showed me his National Geographic photos. Those old photos still hang in his room, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don't go in there anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies, and maybe one day, my own photo in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, despite his temper. Mom smiled. "At least he's coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your dedication, even on cold days!" I smiled back as I peeled my banana. "It'll be warmer in South America," I said. "If I find sponsors for my expedition." She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. In the backyard, I hurried to the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study, where there was an unframed painting on the table, leaning against the wall. It was clearly one of Grandpa's works, but it was different from anything he had done before and was obviously unfinished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. It showed a river that took up most of the scene; it wasn't a river she recognized and might not even be real, just imaginary. The picture was strange and shapeless, yet beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely noticeable, just a hint of green that the eye almost missed, as it was drawn to the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it seemed right that way. It felt like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long, rich summer. Mum spoke again. "It's got a name." There was something in her voice—too casual, too detached—that showed her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his pictures. He just painted them and let others figure them out, if they could. Mum turned the picture over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed to have a special meaning, as if they were important to her, but she didn't know why. And there was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it—for him to be so specific. Still, he hasn't finished it yet, so maybe he's going to add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual picture, especially having a name. I guess you can imagine his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to waste time telling every idiot..." "Ignoramus, he said." "...every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone who came along, they'd never get any work done. And he said..." Mum interrupted her, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting, since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually just to say the muse wasn't being kind to him that day, or that he'd have to be nice to the muse because he had a difficult part to work on, or something like that. He never suggested the muse had anything to do with her. She always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a human being. And it was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, having any influence over someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally cut the carpet. I'm not saying that's what happened, just that it could have. I didn't wake up thinking, "Today I'll cut a hole in my carpet." It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm quite unlucky that way.

What I was really trying to do was find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's really cute, small, painted white with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass-panelled doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and milkmaids. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I always loved her corner cabinet, so I was thrilled when she gave it to me! But it's a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle, so it needs to stand in a corner.

I only have two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one, like a broom cupboard, is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But since Angela is only fifteen, I'll be in my small room for a while. I don't mind; I like my cosy little room. It's like a nest, with a sloping roof and a window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. If I could just cut a couple of centimetres off the bottom...

That's when I had the idea. If I couldn't cut the cabinet, maybe I could cut a hole in the carpet. It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to "think outside the box." And that's exactly what I was doing!

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in a house, secretly taking things from the normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be difficult to meet fans' expectations. People who love the book have strong opinions about how it should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to tell me I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' point of view, not the humans', which made filming more complicated. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when filming them walking across a room or going on a mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to get the Borrowers' perspective. They wore out many pairs of jeans doing this! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous US director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I especially remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh so much. In the story, there's a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary they didn't have to act. One important thing for me, which other directors struggled with, was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls' clothes. This made it almost impossible for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn't sit during breaks and couldn't take the dress off because she was sewn into it every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don't think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers' home had to be shot with the actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each should look – I did 2,000 by the end. They weren't accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn't allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists who aren't there. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the people pretending to be friends, and the requests for free tickets to my dad's concerts. "Everything's going to be fine," I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me to face this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted—to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the band is here for recording, we're staying permanently. I chose this school because I want to meet regular kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so normal. 

I walk into the school's main office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I say to the secretary. "Name?" she asks, not very friendly. "Desert McGraw." "Desirée?" she asks, leaning closer. "Desert," I repeat. She seems confused but types "McGraw" on her keyboard. That's one good thing—few people recognize my last name because my dad uses a stage name. "What grade?" "Eleventh." "One second, it's printing," she says, then hands me the schedule. English Literature is my first class. Great, I like English. I'll be late, though. It's in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night to avoid looking lost. When I reach the door, the teacher is already calling roll. "Aurelio Gonzalez." "Here." I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. Perfect, no one will suspect anything! "Nice shoes," she whispers. I look at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oops, maybe not so perfect. "Thanks," I say. The teacher pauses. "Desert... McGraw?" she asks. "Here." She smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After discussing the books we'll read this year, she lets us socialize. All teachers should do this. "So why'd you move here?" my new friend asks. I have options. Do I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? "We need a change, Desert," he said, "and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed." Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else choose a studio near the sand? "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. Yes, lies work better. "What does he do?" she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out eventually. But I can pretend to be normal for a while. "He's an artist," I say, playing with my backpack zipper. "Cool. I'm Becca, by the way." And she doesn't seem to care. Perfect.

The average American teenage girl today is expected to do a lot: be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is what being a teenager in America is like now. Teenagers can't just go to school and be average; they need to stand out. Being average is not enough, and not having big ambitions is seen as laziness. 

Many adults forget how much pressure teenagers face today. They have lots of homework, tests, extra activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to have a social life, says teenager Kristen Loose. Despite these pressures being normal for teenagers now, negative stereotypes about them still exist, often spread by the media. These stereotypes include being lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers might fit these descriptions, it's not fair to label the whole generation this way.

Kristen Loose points out that people often think teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or on their phones. She believes this is mostly wrong. She admits she keeps her phone close, but not just for fun. It's a tool that helps make life easier for teens and those responsible for them. Students are expected to have instant access to the world and be reachable at all times, which can look like phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can work anywhere and do homework on the go. Schoolwork and activities now need attention 24/7, adding to the stress of already busy teens.

Many teenagers start their day at 6 or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight. Their days are full of school, activities, family duties, and homework. They often get less than the recommended nine hours of sleep. A survey by the US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20% of teens get enough sleep, and 28% fall asleep in school at least once a week due to lack of sleep.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she has about 18 hours of free time a week, which isn't much out of 168 hours. She doesn't waste this time on social media or TV but focuses on volunteering. Olsen believes the stereotype is that teenagers only care about themselves and their immediate interests. However, she enjoys volunteering and making a positive impact in her school and community. 

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers might change, but they will still be proving it wrong and pushing the world forward. There will be a new generation of students making a big impact even before they finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, near the Sierra Nevada mountains. Over the past few years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a long-term science project with a twist: it's part astronomy experiment, part adventure, which attracts teenagers. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. These occur when a rock or metal piece enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside was a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer to track temperature changes. Two GPS trackers were on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by someone from a nearby state, was used to inflate the balloon, which grew to the size of a small car. An older boy had driven seven hours to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he said. For kids in this club, that's normal. Finally, it was time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chanted, and the balloon began to rise. Some of them ran and tracked its path with flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There was a quiet, shared sense of wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside, looking at the clear sky, hard to believe it was just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city of about 4 million people. I watched a boy climb into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. ‘We're the only ones talking,’ said one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispered another. A meteor shot across the sky. As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, and the balloon expanded until it was almost the size of a house. Then it burst in a dramatic explosion. A parachute helped the equipment inside the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day, using the GPS trackers. Getting it back wasn’t easy, but that was part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box almost always lands in remote areas. ‘To me, recoveries are a huge part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, who noted they've lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey has been becoming more familiar with this landscape in a way you never normally would.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but to get it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. Then they had to decide whether to drive or walk – it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. ‘It's important to remember that these students are native to the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader said. ‘What may seem wild and dangerous to some is just a way of life to others.’ In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, high on a flat rock, in the middle of a waterfall. The camera hadn't recorded any shooting stars. It was a bit disappointing, but it was also a chance to discuss the effects of atmospheric waves and how they might work above mountain ridges. And it was another adventure story to share with others.

Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, didn't interest her much until she was fifteen. Her interest started by accident. Her younger brother was fascinated by dinosaurs, a common phase for kids, which she hadn't gone through. She helped him with a science project and found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology. It amazed her, and she realized she wanted to pursue it. I asked her about the support she received, as Palaeontology wasn't a typical career choice for young people then. She recalls meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous despite being young. She was nervous, worried he might find her annoying, but he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel comfortable.

I asked Chloe about how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV. She admits that films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs, but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She finds the portrayal of palaeontologists in movies misleading, often showing them as either eccentric geniuses or awkward geeks. Films don't accurately show their daily work. Chloe explains that her job is varied, involving digging up dinosaur bones, working in labs, analyzing fossils, and writing for scientific journals. Communicating scientific findings to the public is also important to her, though not a daily task. She believes in addressing misunderstandings about science and enjoys reaching out to young people to spark their interest in the natural world and science.

Chloe was involved in the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, which aimed to accurately portray dinosaurs. She advised the makers, who were knowledgeable, and mostly checked that the dinosaurs shown lived in the same time period. The program attracted audiences of all ages because it depicted dinosaurs more realistically than movies like Jurassic Park.

I asked why dinosaurs continue to fascinate us and remain a research focus. Chloe thinks they appeal to our inner explorer. They draw our imagination to the unknown and the possibility of discovery. In a world that feels smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us there's still much to discover. Palaeontology, she says, is like time travel.

I'm going to say this just once: when you're traveling by car with your family, even if you're six years old, you probably know you're not "there yet," even if you keep asking "Are we there yet?" The truth is, once you arrive, it's not "there" anymore; it's "here." So, if you think you might be "there," you should ask "Are we here yet?" And no one wants to be "there" more than the parents who hear that question repeatedly on long car trips. Seriously, what are we kids complaining about? Think about it. Wouldn't you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing expected of you? You can watch DVDs you haven't seen, listen to music, or do puzzles, while the scenery passes by outside the window. In the front seat, there's mom or dad, acting as co-pilot, handing out juice boxes and cookies, adjusting the radio and temperature, making sure everything runs smoothly. Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying—like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. He can't do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then it's his other foot, then a hand, and soon he's in my space, and a fight starts. The driver and co-pilot reach back to separate us as the car speeds up and swerves. They tell the younger sibling to stay in his seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a while. The beautiful scenery continues to pass by. Soon after, I'm trying to read, and I feel a breeze on my arm. But the car isn't going fast, and the window isn't open. Where's it coming from? My brother is in the next seat, quietly blowing air onto me. He's on his side, not touching me, so he's technically not doing anything wrong. Just breathing? What's the problem with that? The anger builds. Tim gets yelled at, and there's more swerving. Then things calm down again—for now. Over the years, Dad has developed ways to handle us kids in the back seat. For example, when we ask "Are we there yet?" he often says, "Yes. We're here. Get out of the car." "But Dad, we're still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour." "Oh, well, maybe we're not there yet." That keeps us quiet for a while. You know you're finally "there" when the adults get out of the car and move as far away as they can from the kids who have annoyed them for hours. So remember: if mom and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is no. You're not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains their motivation: "With so much technology, everyone is busy on their phones. We wanted to bring people together without screens. It's natural for us to communicate with each other."

The games in their café are called 'Eurogames'. These games have gentle themes like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources, keeping everyone involved until the end. This idea was improved in 'co-operative' games, where players win or lose as a team, encouraging more social interaction. One example is Pandemic, a game by North American designer Matt Leacock, where players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. He recalls, "When I played it with friends, we felt scared and excited. Everyone felt good at the end, win or lose. I wanted to create something like that."

Leacock's love for board games started in childhood. He often felt disappointed with games, so with his uncle's help, he would redesign them. Pandemic became very successful, and its sequel included more storytelling. Leacock says, "It's like an electronic game where you develop characters, get new rules, and the world changes. It's an unfolding story."

Interestingly, the growth of video games has helped the success of modern board games. Video games have made playing games more normal. Ben Hogg, from a leading games company, says, "Everyone with a smartphone plays at least one game. More people are open to playing games now."

Video games once offered social interaction in arcades or with friends at home. But as multiplayer games moved online, players became physically separated. Some people who enjoyed video games started looking for games to play with others in person. John and Zuzi's café shows that tabletop gaming is more than just fun. In our online world, games are something to share in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many false beginnings. Jamie's mother was a great singer and taught him to play the guitar. Growing up, he only listened to a local radio station for middle-aged people, which influenced his musical taste. He didn't hear a contemporary song until he was 12. Around that time, he had to choose between playing tennis at a national level and music, as he spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. Although he was good at tennis, he realized it wasn't what he wanted to do for life because it was too much hard work.

At 17, Jamie left school to pursue a career in music. He formed a duo with a friend who was a decent guitarist but not as passionate about a music career. Jamie told his parents about his dream, explaining that he had been writing lyrics during economics lessons and playing the piano while others played outside. His father gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels wanted him as a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend.

Jamie found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he switched to another label to release a new album, but fame and fortune didn't come. He felt that as an artist, he was often in the wrong place at the wrong time, but as a writer, he was in the right place. Writing for others became his strength. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK that labels rely on to help new artists start their careers. Sometimes, he explains to these artists that aiming for chart success is nothing to be ashamed of. He encourages them to write songs that are both amazing and likely to sell well.

Jamie speaks openly about wanting to write hit songs that reach number one, which is refreshing in the pop music world. He doesn't come across as arrogant; he simply knows he has a talent for writing hits. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his goal. When he works in the studio, he aims to create music that is globally successful and the best of the next year. It's not just about being trendy; he wants to write classic modern pop songs.

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity: he's very famous online but might be unknown to people who don't watch videos of bike stunts. He is a 'street trials cyclist,' which means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online. When I met him for an interview at a BMX park on a Saturday morning, many local boys and even older people recognized him and called him a 'legend.' After seeing his skills, I agreed with them. I was impressed by his bravery and creativity, even though I was skeptical at first. Before each stunt, he explains what he plans to do, and it's hard to believe he can succeed. But after he does, he seems uninterested in my praise and a bit down. Despite his online fame, Tony doesn't enjoy being a celebrity. He finds it hard to socialize and prefers doing things rather than talking about them. This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and camera technology. He acknowledges that this technology allows him to make a living, but he feels uncomfortable with how much people focus on screens. However, he appreciates that he can earn money from what would have been just a hobby in the past. From my experience interviewing top athletes, I know that two key factors turn a passionate child into a top competitor: energy and the ability to overcome disappointment. These are often more important than talent and help athletes persist despite failures. In risky sports, mental strength is crucial. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on relatively easy obstacles but kept trying until he succeeded. Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some think he's reckless and takes unnecessary risks. Tony responds that these critics don't understand the sport and haven't ridden a trials bike. They don't know the technical details or that he gets expert advice to minimize risks. Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He believes it's important to be aware of dangers. Some people never feel scared, but Tony feels fear and finds a way to overcome it. He isn't addicted to risk and spends a lot of time planning. Sometimes he rides around to get in the right mindset before a new stunt. He knows he must stay calm before jumping. If he fully commits, he's fine.

Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on several dangerous challenges for charity. She has run a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon River in a small boat. Her latest challenge was walking on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground. She walked between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, just a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her balance and avoid falling, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found high-wire walking to be very different. "The training was a shock," Helen said. "I didn’t realize how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and another hour after practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could continue if I slipped. Every fall hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I got nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!" On the day of the challenge, it was windy. Helen stayed calm by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took her 15 minutes. "That was the scariest thing I’ve done," she said afterward. "I’m glad it’s over!" Despite this, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole using skis, a kite, and a bike.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. Before this, he had written a book about traveling around Canada in a 50-year-old car. He loved motor sports and worked on building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and even used it to go on holiday to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003 due to a knee injury, he finally set off in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries across four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains on their bikes, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further away from home I got, the more amazed people seemed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream, which gave him a serious fever. He was stuck in a hostel bed without medicine for ten long days and had no money for hospital bills or to get back home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using a new tool called a 'night-vision scope' that lets us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have a lot of information about what they do during the day, but not at night, because we didn't have the right equipment before. This new scope gives us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about protecting their habitat. The work is tough. There are four of us, each working six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and note every duck I see. The weather has been challenging – some nights are mild, but often it's wet. It's so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We've only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. Still, I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to what summer will bring – hours in a lab analyzing our results. It will be hard to be indoors, but it's necessary. And I wouldn't change it for anything!

Whenever I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it exists. But it's true! I spend my workdays eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is crucial to ensure that customers receive perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from the company I work for. Every week, I get samples from our factory to check their taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, to choose the best ones for our chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I test and taste the products I create, and I share samples with my colleagues to keep them happy. My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to experiment with, and it's great to have a private space to work in during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I'm in our food lab, and other times I'm traveling abroad to buy raw materials. This can be challenging because I have a young family. However, I love the variety and lack of routine in my job, although the chocolate itself is still my favorite part! People often ask if I get tired of chocolate. I've worked with it for a long time, and I've never felt like I didn't want to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!

Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson is from Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves flying through the air above an amazed audience. During the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, "For a circus career, performers need to avoid doing the same thing all the time – it’s important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great part is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important - circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is crucial, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get injured or only work for a short time each year. But the real issue is planning for the future because you can only perform while you're young, and then you need to think about other options." The course also includes business planning. Many former students have started businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, however, that it's not a profession for making money! "The work usually means not having a regular salary. It’s also competitive - but a lot of fun!"

You might not know her name or recognize her face, but you've probably heard her voice many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She supports the lead singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers aren't good enough to be lead singers, but that's not true—they often need to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! 

"What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I'll be asked to sing," she says. "It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes it's a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I'm often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do the job!"

"Excellent musical skills are essential for my work, along with the ability to learn quickly. There's often no sheet music to look at. I'll never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, plus an orchestra. I was terrified because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough already."

"One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers don't always know which musical range suits the female voice best. By listening to me perform their song, they can figure out how to improve it."

Julie Deane started her business with only basic knowledge of fashion. She created a successful company selling 'satchels,' which are traditional school bags. These bags are now sold in famous stores and are popular with celebrities. Before deciding on satchels, Julie considered various business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She didn't just go with her first thought. When she chose satchels, not everyone agreed with her decision. Julie says, "Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced." She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had no career experience but had a natural talent for business. The design inspiration came from children's storybooks. Although Julie wasn't familiar with fashion blogs, they played a key role in her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel a week. To generate interest, she sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would mention them in their blogs. They did, and interest grew, along with the speed of production. Julie enjoys seeing which celebrity is spotted with a satchel. Instead of spending money on online ads, she uses the internet community to get ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied her satchel design to sell similar products. Because of this, she now ensures she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices, where people love to work. There is now a new factory, and while the building is important, it's the team that makes it a special place.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose how to spend their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard to balance training with schoolwork. As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky found it exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so she could easily attend training sessions after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. At 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky said, "I loved winning competitions for years, but I started to feel tired of it all. When the excitement stops, there's no point." Fortunately, she started a new career. Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. "We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport," she says. "The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, bringing young people together as part of a larger group." The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, "Some people doubt whether celebrity support is always good for a charity. They think celebrities do it for their own publicity, which can hide the charity's real work. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should."

Ana Ronson, a singer-songwriter, grew up in Ireland. Her parents weren't musicians, but music was always present at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. Ana first sang in front of an audience at school, but she was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to gain confidence. After some time in the club, Ana sang with 50 other students at a concert and felt happy. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, "Falling Stars," in just three days and enjoyed it so much that she took a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Although she was the youngest student, she knew more about music than many others. However, Ana felt the teacher didn't listen to her, so she wrote "Something to Say" about her frustration. She posted the song online, and it became very popular. People loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled across Ireland to invite her to join Isotope. At first, Ana was unsure because she didn't know the company and didn't want to be told what to sing. Joss assured her this wouldn't happen, and soon she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and the evening was amazing. Ana prefers writing songs about difficult times rather than happy ones because she feels there's more to express. One of her favorite songs is "Decision," about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it affected him.
