While she hopes fans enjoy her songs, her main goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an amazing trip. I traveled by boat on a guided group tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He’s a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, but I don’t share that interest. However, I had always wanted to visit the area since I saw it on TV as a child. I knew our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally said yes! 

A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to visit. But luckily, the weather forecast for our trip was for calm seas. I was busy at work and didn’t have much time to think about the trip details. But Harry promised he’d taken care of everything, so I stopped worrying. 

After arriving in Canada, we joined the group, packed our limited supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide mentioned that very few people lived along that coast, and indeed, the only other living creatures we saw on the first morning were dolphins and birds. We knew there were islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I just focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water. 

We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches along the coast. They were full of amazing colored fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was great to stop worrying about time. We never forgot lunch or dinner, which we all made together over campfires. When we finally fell asleep on the boats each evening, even though the beds were hard, it felt like stress-free living! 

When it was time to leave, I was sad. How could I return to normal life again? But I knew if I stayed, I’d miss family and friends. I was also looking forward to telling everyone at home about our adventures!

My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father. As a kid, I often went to watch his games. You might think this would make me love basketball, but it actually didn't. I enjoyed telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I usually brought a book to read instead of watching the games. 

When I started secondary school, I was almost a teenager and already two meters tall. My sports teacher noticed my height and asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training session but felt I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, my teacher believed in me more than I did. After a few weeks, I agreed to play against another school. Having my parents watch made me nervous, but it turned out fine in the end.

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did well, even joining an adult team. At fifteen, I moved to a special sports academy in the USA. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn't enjoy being far from my parents at first. Back home, I didn't have much time for friends because of training, so that part didn't change much. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly.

I turned professional at eighteen, three years after moving to the USA. I was taller than most professional players since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight for my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it.

Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college, but I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. After thinking about different options, I decided to train as a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. This job involved showing visitors around the city, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I got to see my city through the eyes of tourists, and it felt new every time! After finishing my studies, I chose to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but I found out that to get a license, I needed to know much more than I had learned. Chicago guides must answer many questions about the city, including its architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I got my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent guide. Tour guiding is not just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds. You need many other skills. You should be entertaining and tell interesting stories, and you must react to changing situations, like if a place is closed when you arrive or a route changes. Tourists want to enjoy a well-organized tour, not hear about problems. I need to make sure visitors are happy with my tours, or they might post a negative review online. Like most tour guides, I know these reviews are important because good reviews attract more customers. That's why making tours fun and stress-free is essential. My enthusiasm and energy usually lead to very good reviews, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago.

My name is Ella, and I'm 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister Josie. Even though she is five years younger than me, we get along quite well. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary, which is a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I wasn't sure if we would have much in common with the other volunteers because they were all much older than us. We were also nervous because it was our first time doing something like this. But in the end, there was nothing to worry about.

One of our main tasks at the sanctuary was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so gathering this took most of the day. Josie found it really hard work, but seeing the elephants enjoy their meal made it worth it for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river using big brushes and soap. I found this really fun, even though I got wetter than the elephants!

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants on foot into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, so we didn't have much space. That was our choice because Josie didn't want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and didn't include meat, which we both prefer to avoid. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff spent the evenings talking and playing games.

Now that we're back in the UK, Josie doesn't talk much about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I'm not sure she's being completely honest. I think she might be a bit upset with herself for not making the most of her time there because she missed her friends too much. But when she looks back, she can see how lucky she was to go there. Maybe she'll go back one day—I definitely will!

I'm Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We don't just sell flowers to people for their friends or homes; we have a variety of customers. Hotels and offices often want flowers for their reception areas, and sometimes we provide flowers for business photo shoots. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was really proud of it.

My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep then, and my friends think I'm crazy, but I love what I do. It's often colder and darker than I'd like, but that's normal for that time of the morning, so I don't mind. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were choosing for myself, I'd probably only pick pink ones because it's my favorite color. But I have to remember that what I like and what customers want can be different. Not all flowers are available all year, so sometimes I can't find what customers want.

I don't enjoy negotiating prices with the flower sellers, but it's part of the job. Flowers aren't cheap, so I try to get the best price. Back at the shop, we check customer orders and arrange the flowers I bought. Then we create flower arrangements and calculate the costs. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some might think this is too much trouble, but I enjoy figuring out how to make the nicest arrangements within a customer's budget. That's what you have to do when you're selling things, and I wouldn't want any other job!

My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest films I want to see, and many films for kids on the weekends. It's close to where I live. However, a year ago, I felt something was missing – the chance to discuss a film in detail with others after watching it. So, with two friends, I started a film club! We decided not to rent a cinema for our screenings. Instead, we choose a different location in the city each month. For example, we rented an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which created the perfect atmosphere for the film, and it was amazing! Some places we use are even free because the owners make money by selling snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We’re happy just to cover our costs – we’re not trying to make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets a bit easier, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We also know how many tickets we’ve sold because everything is online – no more worries about empty seats! There’s still a lot to do, but when people of all ages come up at the end to say they had a great experience, it’s wonderful. The website has been a great help, and we’re now in contact with other film clubs across the country. We’ve visited to see how things are done in different places – but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We’ve started a blog too, because we know most people now go online for film information, rather than reading reviews in local papers. We’ve also tried putting up a few posters in cafés. However, nothing is as effective as word of mouth – people recommending us to their friends. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film – last month we had a movie quiz, which everyone enjoyed.

As a child, taking photographs was my favorite activity. When I turned 15, I wanted to take my hobby further, so I decided to start a special project: taking one photo every day for a year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea, so I began. After a few weeks, I uploaded my photos to a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and share my work with others. I was surprised to find that people liked my perspective and photos. I enjoyed capturing different subjects. Someone suggested that my project would be better if all the photos had a common theme. I agreed and started focusing on nature scenes, especially birds and the sky. Many of my photos were in black and white, which was different from other young photographers who used color. I sometimes doubted my project and almost quit several times. However, I trusted my instincts and became more confident in my style. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher, who told me about a national photography competition for people my age. I entered some photos for fun. I’ll never forget when the judges announced I had won first prize; I was thrilled because my project was important to me. It was the first time I realized my photography might be good enough for a professional career. Now, I have my own photography studio and have never regretted my career choice.

I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try camping, sailing, and learn skills like public speaking, which I had never done before. In the NYC, you can do various activities to challenge yourself and learn new things. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called 'leaders'. When you finish each level, you get a certificate. 

When I first joined, my leader suggested I help organize activities at a local children's club for two hours a week as my first challenge. I wasn't sure about it because I had joined that club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other kids already had their own groups, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to take the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. Soon, I wanted to spend all my free time at the children's club. It became more important to me than just getting the certificate. After finishing the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to continue volunteering at the club because I had built strong relationships with the children. Now, I volunteer there for about four hours a week and always look forward to it.

Because of my experience at the children's club, I have decided that after finishing school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. I had never thought about this career before joining the club. In fact, I hadn't thought much about my future job at all. This has been my favorite part of the NYC so far, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I have earned several other NYC certificates now, and yes, one of them is for camping!

I was born in Denver, USA, and I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, and my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was so young that I hadn't thought about snowboarding, but my dad loved it and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and eventually, I managed well. After that, I quickly developed a love for the sport and improved my skills. I started competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored of snowboarding, but my love for competing and winning has grown stronger as I’ve gotten older, which motivates me to push myself harder. I like not having a fixed plan, and sometimes it works out well, like when I became the first female to score a perfect 100 at a local competition. I wasn’t sure I’d try the jumps that got me this score until I actually started. That achievement boosted my confidence in my abilities. In the summer, I focus on training and my studies since there’s no snow. Although I train every day, it’s nice not to follow a strict diet like in the winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends then. It helps me cope with not being able to do what I love and am really good at. I have to think carefully about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life now, but I also think it’s important to have another option in case I don’t succeed as a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I’m considering whether becoming a doctor is possible if my active life allows time for a college degree. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it my whole life.

When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had and didn't think about the future. For example, I didn't know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I wanted one too. My parents said I could have it only if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I'm grateful to my parents for this because it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn't enjoy it much. My parents suggested I start my own small business instead. I saw my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try it. I found it easier than I expected, even though it looked complicated when I watched her. My friends thought it was boring, but I was excited about it. Mum showed me how to make beautiful things at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewelry to friends and family. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. I needed to know if they were good enough for the public, so I rented a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my jewelry to take home as gifts. Soon, we got calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many employees, but it was just the two of us at a market stall! That's when I realized it could work, and it was time to create a website. Since then, I've made thousands of pounds through my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It's been a lot of fun so far.

When Janine Stuart was just 13, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. The book is partly based on Janine’s own life. In an interview, Janine explained, "Because of my dad's job, my family moved around a lot, so I got good at making new friends. I know what it's like to be the new student in a class, and that helped me write about Amelia, the main character, starting at a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I'm an only child, I had to use my imagination for that." Janine began writing her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to start writing. The year before, she had won first prize in a short story competition on a young writers’ website. Because of this, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publisher, they were eager to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s novel was available in bookshops. One review of Being Amelia notes that even though the cover shows happy teenagers, the characters in the story face some tough challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer says that even though Janine is young and the novel isn't very long, she has shown she is a better writer than some other bestselling authors. Janine is still getting used to being a famous writer: "At first, I hid when people recognized me on the street, but now it's OK. I’d like to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, spending time with friends gives me ideas to write about!"

I'm Tom, I'm fifteen, and three years ago my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. It all began when my dad was asked to be the castle's manager. He works for an organization that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open to the public. He was happy because he thought he might not get such a great opportunity again, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree that he should take the job. We were mainly thinking about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our cozy home across the water, and there was no school. However, once we moved, we quickly adapted to island life. The castle isn't very beautiful, but our apartment in it is comfortable. The island feels lively in summer because it attracts many visitors, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we only see the other families living on the island, and there aren't as many teenagers as I had hoped. The adults all support each other and help with repairs on the island, which often requires a lot of hard work. The biggest change for me was traveling by boat every day to my old school. I was excited about going on stormy days with big waves, but the ferries don't run then! I've learned that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I also miss the last ferry home, which is worrying. So when schoolmates come to stay with me, I always tell them to hurry up! But we often get amazing views, like when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it's so foggy you can't see anything, and then a few hours later, it's sunny again – it's still incredible when that happens, even after living here for a while. Of course, we do get terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to avoid damage. But then I remind myself it's been here for centuries – and it's still standing!

I live in a house surrounded by beautiful countryside in Scotland. I've always loved nature and wild animals, and six years ago, I started a new hobby—birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural environment. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to tell different species apart and find the best places to see them. It was amazing, and after returning home, I joined a local young birdwatchers' club. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I've almost reached that because on family holidays abroad, I've had the chance to see birds from other countries too. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities, so I can add new birds to my list! I've been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I thought I might see my 200th species. I wasn't too disappointed when it didn't happen, though, as I've learned that you have to be patient with this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers enjoyed it and commented that it looked like a fascinating hobby. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching to the school. I didn't feel nervous until just before they introduced me and I walked onto the stage. I knew I'd remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching me! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I'd prepared well and they really enjoyed it. I might even do another one next year! I'm lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think of becoming birdwatchers, but there are actually plenty of birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think that birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, whatever their age, and it doesn't have to cost much money.

I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and soon I became a decent player. My family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they probably thought the same would happen with football. But it didn’t. I was already dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one referee noticed I was a talented player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. She was impressed and invited me to join her club. I couldn’t believe it at first because I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But I started training regularly with a big club when I was just 13. I improved a lot after that. Even so, some people doubted I’d become a star player, which made me a bit upset. But my coach encouraged me to be myself and believe in myself. He even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I expected! I ran harder than ever because I didn’t want the other players to blame me if we lost. By pure luck, I scored the winning goal. Despite the large crowd, I could clearly hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, the team carried me around the pitch. It was fantastic! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals. Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and give them a chance to talk to other players in my club. It will show them the professional environment and encourage them to believe they could play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach’s advice to me: you’ll have good times, but be ready for bad times too. I’ve had very few bad times, though, so I’ve been lucky!

In recent years, both in the UK and internationally, there has been a trend in higher education to involve students in research early in their studies. This shift acknowledges that research is not just for famous scholars or scientists making big discoveries. Instead, research is a fundamental way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills are valuable not only in academics but also in the workplace because they help us think critically about the world and our work. As a student, you contribute to knowledge by asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? These questions are at the heart of research.

Research can range from groundbreaking, complex studies by highly trained experts to everyday inquiries that involve careful work and thoughtful questions about various topics. Most students have already done some research, whether in school projects or everyday life, like planning a holiday or fixing things at home. In college, having an enquiring mind, identifying problems, critically evaluating information, and forming your own ideas are key learning activities.

Some students might find this challenging, especially if they come from educational backgrounds where knowledge is seen as fixed and learned from authority figures like teachers and textbooks. In places like the UK, US, and much of Europe and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged. This approach can be intimidating, but critical thinking is crucial in research. We need to engage with others' research, think critically about it, and not just accept it as fact. It's important to test ideas, check if they are logical and supported by evidence, and not rely uncritically on information from others.

Cities have always been centers of intellectual activity. In the 18th century, people in London gathered in coffee houses to discuss topics like chemistry and politics. In modern Paris, artists like Pablo Picasso talked about modern art in cafés. However, living in a city is not always easy. Those same London coffee houses also spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. While cities are creative hubs, they can also be overwhelming and unnatural. 

Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are concerning. It's known that city life is tiring, but new research shows it can also dull our thinking. One major issue is the lack of nature, which is surprisingly good for the brain. Studies show that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees. Even brief views of nature can improve brain function because they offer a mental break from city life.

This research is timely because, for the first time in history, most people live in cities. Instead of open spaces, we are packed into crowded urban areas. This has significant effects on our mental and physical health and changes how we think. Walking down a busy street requires your brain to manage many things: distracted people, traffic, and the complex city layout. These tasks drain our mental energy because they force us to constantly focus and refocus our attention. 

Natural environments, on the other hand, don't demand as much mental effort. This concept is called attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He suggested that being in nature can restore our attention. Nature captures our attention without causing stress, unlike city noises like police sirens. This allows our minds to relax and recharge.

Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the effects of city life and sought to integrate nature into urban areas. Parks like Central Park in New York offer a break from city life and can quickly improve brain function. While people try various methods to boost cognitive performance, like energy drinks or office redesigns, simply walking in nature seems to be more effective.

Despite the mental challenges of city life, cities continue to grow. Even in the digital age, they remain centers of intellectual life. Research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same urban features that challenge our attention also drive innovation. The concentration of social interactions in cities fuels creativity. Just as 18th-century London was a hub of intellectual breakthroughs, modern cities like Cambridge, Massachusetts, thrive as creative centers. Less crowded cities might generate less innovation over time.

The challenge is to reduce the negative psychological effects of city life while keeping its benefits. After all, there are times when people crave the excitement of the city over the calm of nature.

Where should we look for the mind? It might seem obvious to say that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques to support this idea. However, I believe that the study of the mind shouldn't be limited to just the brain. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, showing that objects and tools also play a role in human thinking. Archaeology shows us that things like stone tools, jewelry, engravings, clay tokens, and writing systems have been important in human evolution and shaping the mind. So, I suggest that what is outside the head might also be part of the mind.

It's easy to see why people equate the mind with the brain. Most of our knowledge about the mind comes from studying people in isolation from their usual surroundings. This makes sense for neuroscientists because of the limitations of brain-scanning machines. But this approach often overlooks the fact that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I don't deny the importance of the brain in cognition, but I believe the mind is more than just the brain. We should explore the idea that human intelligence extends beyond the body into culture and the material world.

This is where my theory, Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET explores how objects become extensions of our minds, like when we use clay to make numbers or a stone to create a tool. It also looks at how these interactions have changed over time and what they mean for our thinking. This approach offers new insights into what minds are and how they work by changing our understanding of what objects do for the mind.

Consider a blind person with a stick. Where does this person's self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick shows how minds and objects can be continuous. It also illustrates the flexibility of the human mind: using a stick, the blind person turns touch into sight, and the stick plays an active role. The brain treats the stick as part of the body. This example reminds us that human intelligence is adaptable and can change by incorporating new technologies.

I see the human mind as an ongoing project, always evolving. Throughout history, the 'stick' has taken many forms, from ancient stone tools to the internet. Its main role has been as a pathway, not a boundary. Through these 'sticks,' humans explore and understand the world, and also shape their future. This is different from how animals use tools. For humans, tools satisfy our curiosity and desire to learn. This unique human trait explains why we create things and how these things, in turn, shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity – our minds are flexible and change as they interact with the material world.

I want to include materiality in our understanding of cognition. MET offers a new way to see how different forms of material culture, from stone axes to smartphones, have defined and transformed us. Mind-changing technology might sound futuristic, but humans have been using it since we first evolved.

Photography has greatly changed how we see the world and has had a big impact on civilization, especially in the United States. In the U.S., photography quickly became a part of culture at all levels, from practical and scientific uses to industrial and artistic ones. It also opened up new forms of entertainment. Many historians believe that photography is the U.S.'s greatest contribution to the visual arts, more so than any other art form. This shows how important photography has become in U.S. culture and thought, and to understand its impact, we need to look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century.

Why was photography so popular? First, because it was a mechanical process, it fit well with the growing interest in technology in the U.S., where change was seen as a normal part of life. Just like steam power, railroads, and electricity made the world feel smaller by improving communication and travel, photography brought the wonders of the world into people's homes with amazing immediacy. Second, the camera was the best tool for showing one's self-image in a country where personal and national identities were always being created and recreated. Third, the camera was important for creating and keeping family memories, even if they were somewhat idealized. Lastly, the realistic nature of photographs matched the U.S. artists' focus on realism and everyday life. Every photograph draws attention to something the photographer wants us to see, saying, "This, you should see!" Because photographs are made by machines, they are seen as records of events, people, or things, giving them a sense of objectivity. However, since they are taken by individuals, they also reflect a personal point of view.

People often think they understand a photograph because they recognize the subject, which is why photography is sometimes called a "universal language." But the meaning of photographs is more complex. No image is shown to us without some context that affects how we understand it, like a newspaper caption or its placement in a gallery. To understand a photograph historically, we need to consider its purpose and how it was first seen. The same photograph can have different meanings in different contexts.

For a long time, the camera's role in art was not widely acknowledged, but now it is very important for contemporary artists. Since the time of U.S. artist Andy Warhol, who used photographs in his paintings and silk screens, artists have been using photographs in many ways. In short, photography has become an essential part of art, working alongside painting to shape our ideas of representation before the camera was invented.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and one of the founders of modern psychology, described psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still useful today. We all have a mental life, so we have some idea of what this means. However, even though we can study mental life in animals like rats and monkeys, it remains a complex concept. James, like most psychologists, was mainly interested in human psychology. He believed it included basic elements: thoughts and feelings, a physical world in time and space, and a way to understand these things. This understanding is personal and private, coming from our own thoughts, feelings, and experiences, and may not always align with scientific facts. 

We often act as amateur psychologists when we give opinions on complex psychological topics, like whether brainwashing works, or when we explain why people behave in certain ways, such as feeling insulted or unhappy. Problems arise when people have different understandings. Formal psychology tries to find methods to decide which explanations are most likely correct in a situation. Psychologists help us distinguish between subjective thoughts, which can be biased, and scientific facts. 

Psychology, as defined by James, is about the mind or brain. Although psychologists study the brain, they don't fully understand how it influences our hopes, fears, and behaviors. It's hard to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and forming hypotheses about what's happening inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective and verifiable, but the mind's workings aren't directly observable like an engine. We can only infer them from behavior. Psychology is like solving a crossword puzzle, using clues from careful observation and analysis. 

Psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and control or modify processes. Achieving these goals helps us understand our experiences and apply findings to real life. Psychological research has improved teaching methods, machine safety, and emotional well-being by helping people communicate better. Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, scientific investigation began only about 150 years ago. Early psychologists used introspection, or self-reflection, to study the mind. While introspection is still considered, it has limitations. As Sir Francis Galton noted, it only shows a small part of brain activity. William James compared it to trying to see darkness by quickly turning on a light. Today, psychologists prefer to base theories on careful observations of behavior rather than personal reflections.

In a warehouse in a business park in Michigan, USA, there is a place known as the Museum of Failed Products. This museum, owned by a company called GfK, displays products that were taken off the market because almost no one wanted to buy them. The museum's owner, Carol Sherry, believes each product tells a sad story about the designers, marketers, and salespeople who created it. Surprisingly, the museum is a successful business. You might think that companies would keep their own collections of failed products, but many executives visit the museum because they haven't done so. The museum started by accident. Robert McMath, a former marketing professional, began collecting samples of new products in the 1960s, not specifically failures. He discovered that most products fail, so his collection naturally included many unsuccessful ones.

Today's culture of optimism might explain why these failed products exist. Each product likely went through meetings where no one realized it was doomed. Even if they did, marketers might have invested more money to force some sales and save face. Little effort is made to understand why these products failed, and people involved often avoid discussing it. This focus on optimism is common in the growing self-help industry, where "positive visualization" is popular. The idea is that imagining success makes it more likely to happen. Neuroscientist Tali Sharot found that our brains might be wired to be overly optimistic, which can help us survive. Her research shows that well-balanced people often have an overly positive view of their ability to influence events, unlike those with depression.

However, psychologist Gabriele Oettingen found that "positive fantasies about the future" can reduce motivation. People who imagined having a successful week at work often achieved less. Psychologist Carol Dweck suggests that our beliefs about ability affect how we handle failure. People with a "fixed theory" mindset think ability is innate, so failure is a sign they aren't good enough. For example, a sports star who believes he is a "natural" might not practice enough to reach his potential. In contrast, people with an "incremental theory" mindset see failure as a chance to grow. Dweck compares this to weight training: muscles grow by being pushed to their limits. Having an incremental mindset is a happier way to live, whether or not it leads to success.

Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is that? We might think we know, but professional sports are changing quickly, and what we used to believe is now being questioned. Two main factors are challenging the idea of home advantage: science and money. Sports scientists are exploring what helps players perform their best, leading to many theories about home advantage. On the other hand, financial interests question if home advantage should matter at all, as players are paid well and should perform well anywhere.

What about the fans? Would it matter if a team like Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their support is crucial for the team. Fans often think their cheering leads to goals, but they forget the times when their noise didn't result in success. However, one fan belief is supported by science: home fans influence referees. In an experiment, referees who heard crowd noise were less likely to call fouls against the home team compared to those who watched in silence. This suggests referees avoid making decisions that would anger the home crowd.

Studies show that home advantage has decreased in major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the 1890s, home teams in England's Football League won about 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. Travel used to be difficult, but now players travel in luxury, and stadiums are more similar. Despite these changes, home advantage varies by sport. Basketball has the strongest home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. This might be because basketball relies more on teamwork, which is boosted by playing at home.

Another factor could be players' testosterone levels, which are higher before home games. This might relate to a natural urge to defend home territory. In the recent Rugby World Cup, underdog teams won at home against stronger opponents, showing the power of home advantage. As one referee said, "It's the law of the jungle out there."

Text: "‘The more I practise, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about fifty years ago. This saying is famous in sports and is valued by dedicated athletes and their coaches. The quote's origin is debated, with claims for other golfers of that time. Its meaning is also not straightforward. Player didn't mean 'lucky' literally; he was speaking ironically. His real message was: ‘The more I practise, the better I get.’ But how much better can one get? This question is central to the nature-nurture debate in sports: is talent something you're born with, or can it be developed? 

The debate isn't balanced; nurture, or practice, has been seen as more important. This idea is largely due to psychologist Anders Ericsson, who proposed that becoming an expert in any field requires 10,000 hours of practice. This theory inspired Malcolm Gladwell's book "Outliers" and others like "Talent Is Overrated" and "Bounce: The Myth of Talent and the Power of Practice." These books suggest that practice is the key to success, and that 10,000 hours is enough to make anyone an expert. 

However, in his book, Epstein argues that this isn't always true. He points out a flaw in studies about excellence: they often only look at successful people. Science is better at explaining why an elite athlete is successful after the fact. Epstein explores why some people have certain abilities and others don't, considering factors like environment, support, opportunity, and determination. His research takes him around the world, from Kenya to Sweden, and even to the Arctic. 

In Alaska, Epstein learns that in the world's toughest sled dog race, the husky dogs' drive and desire are crucial, suggesting a link between genes and traits we think are voluntary. This challenges the idea that commitment and determination are just choices. What if, as with the huskies, an individual's drive also has a genetic component? 

Epstein highlights the complexity of the topic. He distinguishes between 'hardware' (nature) and 'software' (nurture) and agrees that in elite athletes, both are necessary. He doesn't dismiss the importance of training or environment, suggesting that if Jamaican sprinter Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have become a good basketball player instead of the fastest man in history. But Epstein also looks at cases where genetics are so important that they can't be ignored. He examines race and gender, asking: ‘If only practice matters, why do we separate men and women in sports?’ Sometimes the most obvious questions are the best ones."

A recent international report shows that many children in wealthy countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks why this is happening. In her book, "Kith," she suggests that children are unhappy because they spend too much time indoors, in front of screens, and have lost touch with nature. This idea matches other discussions about modern childhood. A follow-up study interviewed children and found that many would be happier if they could spend more time outside. People over 40 often remember their own childhoods fondly, recalling how they played outside freely, which they believe was healthier than the protected lives of today's children. However, they don't often realize that they are the ones who have created these protective environments for their kids, avoiding risks like playing in old sheds.

Griffiths' book includes strong arguments about the fear of outdoor dangers and how it benefits the toy and gadget industry, which sells products to keep children entertained indoors. She also criticizes trends like giving medication to restless children or making them wear goggles for playground games. While some of these rules might be exaggerated, Griffiths expresses her frustration clearly and passionately. She also discusses childhood freedoms and restrictions, from fairy tales to school rules. Although her arguments are appealing, Griffiths sometimes takes them too far and ignores important counter-arguments. For example, she compares modern treatment of children to a form of racism, which seems extreme.

Griffiths is a romantic when it comes to children, often seeing them in an idealized way. She believes children should have the freedom to explore and take risks, arguing that they need small accidents to learn how to avoid bigger ones later. However, she doesn't explain how to ensure these accidents are "the right size." Also, not all children may want the adventurous life she describes. Some children are naturally cautious and prefer staying at home. Perhaps the real issue is forcing all children into the same lifestyle, whether keeping them inside or pushing them outside.

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, so I have spent a lot of time in school. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this skill doesn't come from my education. Most life problems can't be solved with complex formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity, which come from life experiences. For children, these experiences come from play. My recent research focuses on the importance of play for children's development. All young mammals, including humans, play, and those with more to learn play the most. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because their lives depend more on learning than on instincts. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they can. Play is how mammals, including humans, have always learned. The most important skills for children to live happy, productive, and moral lives can't be taught in school. These skills are learned through play and include creativity, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling impulses and emotions. Creativity is crucial for economic success. We don't need people to follow instructions like robots or do routine calculations. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. If we can develop thinkers who anticipate obstacles, we will have a strong workforce. This requires creative thinking. A creative mind is a playful mind. Geniuses are adults who keep and build on their childlike creativity. Albert Einstein said school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he regained it after leaving school. He called his innovative work 'combinatorial play.' He developed his theory of relativity by imagining himself chasing a sunbeam. We can't teach creativity, but we can suppress it with schooling that focuses on imposed questions rather than children's own questions. Even more important than creativity is the ability to get along with others, care about them, and cooperate. Children are naturally driven to play with others, and this play helps them learn social skills, fairness, and morality. Play is voluntary, meaning players can quit if they want. This makes play the most democratic activity. School has become more demanding: breaks are shorter, homework has increased, and pressure for high grades has grown. Outside school, adult-directed sports have replaced spontaneous games. 'Play dates' with adults present have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play, and adults now feel they must intervene rather than let children solve their own problems. These changes have been gradual but significant. They are due to social factors like parents' fears, warnings from experts, less cohesive neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. Our children don't need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must reverse the trend of the past fifty years. We must give childhood back to children. They need to follow their natural drive to play and explore to become strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Platforms like Twitter and LinkedIn allow direct contact with potential employers, similar to standing outside an office with a "hire me" sign. However, this access also increases the chance of making mistakes. For example, a young jobseeker in the US contacted a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn, hoping to use her contacts to get a job. The executive was offended by this request and not only rejected it but also sent a harsh, sarcastic reply that went viral. People who saw the note online were shocked, and the executive might regret her tone, though not the message. This incident highlights the risks of using social media for job hunting without knowing how to do it properly. Many young people are making mistakes. 

Ironically, social media like Facebook and Twitter have been central to the social lives of twentysomethings for years. For my generation, social media was a way to escape from parents and teachers, a place to impress and experiment. It was often based on fantasy, where you could have long conversations online and then ignore the person at school. You could change your image overnight with the right pictures or songs on Facebook. But when it comes to professional networking, our experience with social media can be a disadvantage. Using social media professionally is very different, and some young people don't see the difference. We first gained our online presence by being bold and confident, which might explain why some still think this is a good approach. Just because many people liked your Facebook posts doesn't mean you can use LinkedIn to show employers you're worth hiring. We need to understand that what we learned about social networking as teenagers doesn't apply now, and we must meet employers' standards to succeed in the job market.

One common complaint from employers about young job seekers on professional networking sites is that they are too familiar and seem arrogant. This reinforces the stereotype of our generation as entitled. In reality, many of us are desperate to find jobs, which is why we turn to social media. This impression of arrogance can harm the job prospects of young people who actually have the skills and motivation to be valuable employees. So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly explain who you are and what you can offer them, like doing research or helping in some way. This approach increases your chances of getting a positive response. Avoid sending impersonal, generic emails, and keep your tone humble to avoid offending the recipient. Remember, social media can be a great way to make useful contacts, but it requires careful handling to avoid closing doors.

Text: Predicting the future of newspapers is very difficult. If you look at the numbers, newspapers seem to be in trouble. Since 2000, the circulation of most UK national newspapers has dropped by a third to half. In the USA, the Pew Research Centre reports that only 26% of people now get their news from newspapers, compared to 45% in 2001. Many people predict that printed newspapers will disappear in the next 15 years. However, history shows that old media often survive. In 1835, a New York journalist claimed that books and theatre were outdated, but both have survived alongside newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio has thrived despite TV, and cinema has competed with videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records have become popular again, with online sales increasing by 745% since 2008. Newspapers were once new media too, but it took centuries for them to become the main source of news. This was partly because it only became possible and affordable to produce news for a large audience in the mid-19th century, thanks to the steam press, railway, and telegraph. Another reason was the new idea that everything is constantly changing and we need regular updates, which was not common in medieval times. Today, we expect change. In medieval times, people only noticed the changing seasons and unexpected disasters like famine or disease. Life was seen as cyclical, with important truths repeating. Journalism as a profession only really started in the 19th century, and even then, there was no clear reason why people needed regular news. Regular newspaper publication can be limiting. Online news allows readers to check updates based on their interests and the importance of events. Advanced search engines and algorithms let us personalize news. When big stories happen, online news can provide minute-by-minute updates. Mistakes and misunderstandings can be quickly corrected. There are no space limits, so stories can be detailed, and full documents can be accessed. This is very different from traditional newspapers. However, many online news providers focus on being first with the news and generating reader comments, which can create confusion. In medieval times, news was shared in busy places like markets or taverns, where truth mixed with rumors. In some ways, we are returning to that. Newspapers have not always been great at explaining how the world works. They might face extinction, or they might find a way to help us understand our complex world.

If humans were truly comfortable under the light of the moon and stars, we would enjoy the darkness, seeing the midnight world as clearly as many nocturnal animals do. However, we are creatures of the day, with eyes suited for sunlight. This is a fundamental part of our genetics, even if we don't often think of ourselves as daytime beings, just like we don't always think of ourselves as primates or mammals. This explains why we have changed the night by filling it with artificial light. This control over the night is similar to building a dam on a river. While it has benefits, it also causes problems known as light pollution, which scientists are just beginning to study. Light pollution mainly comes from poor lighting design, where artificial light shines into the sky instead of being directed downwards where it is needed. This poorly designed lighting brightens the night, changing the natural light levels and rhythms that many living things, including humans, have adapted to. Wherever artificial light enters the natural world, it affects life processes like migration, reproduction, and feeding. For most of human history, the idea of 'light pollution' would have been meaningless. Imagine approaching London on a moonlit night around 1800, when it was the world's largest city. Nearly a million people lived there, using candles, torches, and lanterns for light. Only a few homes had gas lighting, and public gaslights wouldn't appear for another seven years. From a few miles away, you would have smelled London before seeing its faint glow. We've illuminated the night as if it were empty, but that's not true. Among mammals alone, many species are nocturnal. Light is a strong biological force, attracting many species. This effect is so strong that scientists say songbirds and seabirds are 'captured' by searchlights on land or gas flares on marine oil platforms, flying around them until they fall. Birds migrating at night often crash into brightly lit tall buildings, with young birds on their first journey being most affected. Some birds, like blackbirds and nightingales, sing at odd hours when exposed to artificial light. It was once thought that light pollution only affected astronomers, who need a clear night sky for their work. Unlike astronomers, most of us don't need an unobstructed view of the night sky for our jobs, but like most creatures, we do need darkness. Ignoring the need for darkness is pointless. It is as important for our health as light; changing our internal clock can cause health problems. The regular cycle of waking and sleeping in our lives reflects the natural cycle of light on Earth. These rhythms are so essential to us that disturbing them is like changing our balance. In the end, humans are as affected by light pollution as frogs near a brightly lit highway. Living in the bright light we created, we have disconnected from our evolutionary and cultural heritage—the light of the stars and the natural rhythms of day and night. Light pollution makes us lose sight of our true place in the universe, forgetting our scale, which is best understood against the backdrop of a deep night with the Milky Way—the edge of our galaxy—arching overhead.

The founder of a large international company recently announced that his company will stop tracking employees' paid holiday time. This decision was inspired by an internet company that has a similar policy. The founder said the idea came from an email from his daughter, which seemed like it was written by someone from his media team. Ignoring the way the announcement was made, which might be an attempt to make the policy seem more friendly, we should ask: is this idea practical?

The internet company and the multinational corporation are very different. The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the multinational has 50,000 employees and many different services, like finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want as long as it doesn't harm the business" might work better in a smaller company where employees know each other's workloads and can judge if their absence would be a problem. However, this is still a vague idea.

The founder of the multinational company said employees can take as much leave as they want if they are sure their work and team are up to date and their absence won't harm the business or their careers. But can anyone be that sure? No matter how much you prepare before a holiday, there is always a lot of work waiting when you return. This is just how taking leave works; work piles up while you're away. Following these guidelines might make employees not take leave at all or feel guilty about it. This guilt can lead to stress, and if employees don't take enough leave, it could reduce productivity over time.

There could also be pressure from colleagues and office gossip about who is taking time off and for how long. This pressure already affects decisions like when to start and end the workday. In the corporate world, there is a culture of working late, and this could lead to a "no holiday" culture in a company with unlimited leave, where employees compete for promotions. If the security of having a set amount of leave is removed, people might feel they can't take the leave they need because they don't want to seem lazy. They wouldn't have their legal right to rely on anymore. This policy might make employees feel stuck, unable to take their leave, or they might just stick to their legal rights, making the policy pointless.

Modern technology lets us receive work messages anytime, anywhere, blurring the line between work and free time. The internet company started their unlimited leave policy when employees asked how this new way of working fit with the old time-off policy. If the company couldn't track work hours accurately, why use an outdated standard for time off? But if there are no set work hours, all hours could become work hours. Employees might not know if their work hours are being monitored, leading them to self-monitor, which could be harmful.

Employment laws exist for a reason. Workers are entitled to a minimum amount of paid leave because rest and leisure are important for their mental and physical health. The benefits like increased morale, creativity, and productivity that are expected from the unlimited leave policy can happen without affecting worker well-being. I am doubtful that allowing employees to "take as much holiday as they want" is the real goal or likely result of this policy.

Journal-based peer review is the process where experts in a field review a scientific paper before it is published. It is seen as a way to ensure the quality of research by preventing flawed papers from being published. This process can delay publication by up to a year, raising the question of whether this delay is worth it to ensure trust in scientific literature. The answer is both yes and no, as the system of scientific publishing is changing.

I still believe in some form of peer review before formal publication, but things are shifting. Preprints, which are drafts of papers shared online without peer review, are becoming more common. They allow for quick sharing of new research so others can read, critique, and build on it. Publishing in journals has become more about gaining recognition and advancing careers, which can lead to authors cutting corners and reviewers focusing more on whether a paper is suitable for a journal rather than its quality.

These issues are known, but few are willing to change the current system. However, preprints might offer a solution because they don't require a major change from the norm. Although preprints have been around for twenty years, they are not widely used due to misconceptions that journals won't accept papers already shared as preprints and fears of spreading poor-quality science. However, preprints are open to critique by a global community, which can help maintain quality.

Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, shared her experience with preprints. Her paper critiqued another published paper, which is difficult to do in traditional journals due to anonymous peer review. By using a preprint, the original authors could respond openly, allowing for a transparent discussion. Even if a journal rejects the paper, the preprint and comments remain available, ensuring the work is not wasted.

Preprint archives allow for global scientific discussions that were once private. They can also be a place to share negative results, which are often ignored by journals focused on new discoveries. Papers on preprint archives are read and cited more, showing the effectiveness of this method. By embracing the internet's openness and the collaborative spirit of science, preprints can help focus attention on the research itself, rather than where it is published.

When I ask my literature students to define a poem, they often say it's like 'a painting in words.' These answers don't usually satisfy anyone. So, I tried a different approach. I asked them to pick an object and write two paragraphs: one describing it like a scientist, and another from the object's perspective, titled 'Poem.' One student wrote: 

Poem: I may look strange or scary, but I'm a device that helps people breathe. I'm only used in emergencies and for a short time. Most people will never need me. 

The object? An oxygen mask. This unusual choice helped the class see how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise was fun and sparked a lot of discussion. 

When I was in school, poetry often seemed confusing. I thought of poems as puzzles that blocked true understanding and emotion. After school, many people lose interest in poetry. Sometimes, you come across a poem, and it stands out because it's not like regular prose. It challenges you to read it, but often leaves you feeling let down or confused. Still, you feel good for trying. 

What do we expect from poems? Aren't they supposed to hold deep feelings, beautiful images, thoughtful reflections, or sharp wit? The answer might seem to be yes. But for emotions, we turn to movies; for information or sharp critique, we read online articles. Novels offer escape, paintings please the eye, and music combines lyrics, instruments, and melody in a way nothing else can. 

However, poems have a unique quality: ambiguity. Everyday life is full of it, unlike straightforward reading. But this doesn't fully explain what a poem is. If you search online for 'poem,' it leads you to 'poetry': 'a form of literary art using the beauty and rhythm of language.' This is academic language, but it misses the word's origin. 'Poem' comes from the Greek 'poí?ma,' meaning 'a thing made,' and a poet is 'a maker of things.' So, if a poem is a made thing, what kind of thing is it? 

Poets sometimes compare poems to wild animals—untameable and unpredictable—or to machines—precise and engineered. But these comparisons don't hold up under scrutiny. The value in comparing poems lies in the discussion it creates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change how you think about machines or animals. It helps us rethink familiar ideas and see ordinary things differently. 

Thinking of a poem as a mental object isn't hard, especially when we consider how song lyrics stick in our minds. The mix of words and melody is powerful, like schoolyard rhymes. But aren't words sometimes like sticks and stones? 

Imagine a poem on a newspaper or magazine page, standing out. A poem can impact us like nothing else, even though it's just ink on paper like the prose around it. What about the empty space around the poem—space that could be used for a longer article or ad? A poem is written and rewritten like an article, story, or novel, but it doesn't become a commodity. Publishers promote poetry collections, but few expect them to make money. A poem is not for the market; it's for its own sake. Because of its special place in a magazine or book, a poem can still surprise us, even if just for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. Back then, £70 was a lot of money, and it might have been wiser to spend it on something practical for the house. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first try. Over the years, every brooch and coin I've found has brought me joy because it connects me to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years to find something else that impressed Marion as much.

One dull February afternoon, I had a couple of free hours and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a closer spot that mostly had old farming machinery. The first time my detector beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I tried to ignore it but couldn't leave without checking. I dug down half a meter and was lying in the mud when I saw a rounded, golden ball. I had found brass curtain rails before, so I tried not to get too excited. But as I cleared more dirt, the ball turned into a thick, intricately designed loop. I stopped and stared, then remembered to breathe. It looked like the Great Torc, a famous object from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years old. A torc is a beautiful necklace made of gold and silver, with gold rings at each end, just like the one I found.

I took it to the car and kept looking at it on the drive home. I washed it in my kitchen sink, probably the first clean it had in ages. "Marion!" I shouted, "I've got something for you." She came into the room and stopped when she saw it. "What is it?" she asked. I explained it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn't try it on because we didn't want to damage it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. We had never been burgled, but I was anxious, so I got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it there.

The law says you must report such finds to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as possible before giving it up. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone when I placed the torc on his desk. He turned, still talking, then stopped mid-sentence. The torc was authenticated and eventually sold to my local council. It's now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 proceeds were split between the field's owner and me. But the torc is more than just a lucky find. It's something I've saved for the nation. People ask me, "Now that you've found something so amazing, are you going to stop detecting?" But those brooches and coins are still interesting to me. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn't stop fishing—there's always the chance of catching an even bigger fish tomorrow.

Sleeping is one of my favorite things to do when I travel, but I don't often talk about it because I feel a bit guilty. When friends tell me about their carefully planned trips, filled with activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and listen. I wonder what they would think if they knew my travel plans include time for afternoon naps during Caribbean rainstorms and lazy mornings in Italian sheets. Better sleep is a great benefit of traveling. When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept—more than 12 hours most days. Even with noisy birds nearby, I slept deeply and had vivid dreams. Being away from home and free from alarms and responsibilities, sleep came easily. But I think there's more to it than just relaxing. I believe sleep is part of the travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we experience new sights, sounds, and smells. We take in new cultures, music, and landscapes. Sleep helps us process all this new information, which is why it feels more intense when we travel. Sleep also changes with each place we visit. People often worry about jet lag, but I think adjusting to local customs affects me more than time zones. For example, in Trinidad, people wake up early to avoid the heat, rest around 10 a.m., and become active again in the evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, it takes me days to get used to this new sleep pattern. Once I do, I feel like I've truly arrived. I remember a day in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a big lunch with new friends. After eating, everyone slowly stopped talking and moved to hammocks and sofas to nap. I realized why there were so many pillows around. I joined them and experienced the local custom of the siesta, sharing a part of Dominican life. Travel sleep is memorable because it's different from my usual routine. I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds that come with sleeping in a new place. If 'slow travel' means enjoying every moment instead of rushing, then sleep is the slowest activity of all. Maybe I should stop feeling guilty and tell my friends that travel sleep is an important part of the experience too.

The woman turned away from the mirror. "What do you think? And be honest." Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a soft layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one suits you best," she said diplomatically to her customer. The woman wrinkled her nose and frowned, looking a bit like a bulldog. "But it's so boring," she said. "Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little beauty will make me stand out." She patted the red and black mini top hat on her head. "Yes," she decided, "this is the one I want." Mia knew she couldn't change her mind, so she smiled and agreed that the woman would indeed stand out at the wedding. She thought of her own daughter, Jen, whose thirtieth birthday was today. They were having a family gathering, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious about Jen's friend, Tattie, whom they knew nothing about. When Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie, Mia's husband Jeff had questioned the name. "Tattie," he said, "What sort of name is that?" Mia explained it was short for Tatiana and thought it was nice. Jeff, who disliked anything pretentious, disagreed. He also didn't like Mia's tendency to be overly polite. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat and might have even joked that a dustbin lid would suit her better. "The trouble with you, Mia," he often said, "is that you're too polite for your own good." An hour later, Mia closed the shop and entered Medlar House through the back door. Her commute was only forty seconds. Four years ago, when their youngest child, Luke, left home, Mia decided to convert the unused barn next to their house into a bright space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. "Do you really think there's a demand for hats?" he asked. Mia knew there was, as her friends often complained about finding the perfect hat for special occasions. She was right. From the start, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia's Hats was a success. Women came from far away to her showroom in Little Pelham, where they could try on many hats in a relaxed setting. She encouraged customers to bring their outfits to ensure everything matched. Recently, she expanded her business to include handbags and costume jewelry.

It's a long journey from London to Atlanta, and Lawrence Okoye is reflecting on his incredible sports career. He is confident, but even he is surprised by how far he has come—from competing in the Olympic discus final to possibly joining a major American football team. Despite never playing American football before, Lawrence is likely to be chosen by a top USA team. In Atlanta, he is still learning the details of his new position. The idea that a 21-year-old from London could be selected for a top American sports team is surprising. But Lawrence is used to overcoming doubts. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but delayed it to focus on discus, after playing rugby. In just 20 months, he became the world's fourth-best discus thrower. Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather discus training, aiming for the world championships. He admits that American football was always in the back of his mind, but it was only when he arrived in the USA that he decided to try it. At school in London, he had thought about it, but it seemed unrealistic then. Soon after arriving in America, he learned about NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played, he thought he might be good enough to try out. "Pretty much," he says simply. He applied online. Was he nervous about competing with experienced American football players? "No," he says. "I don't get nervous for many things." He doesn't talk much, but he is confident in his abilities. His performance in tests and drills made him stand out as the most impressive player. "I was very pleased to hear that," he says, showing a rare sign of pride. However, he is also cautious. He has no experience in American football. How can he make it into an NFL team? "Coaches say I have all the qualities needed. It's just about how hard I work," he replies. Will he stay calm while waiting to hear if he's selected? "I will be. There's no pressure on me. Many people say I'll definitely be selected, but I'm not too worried." This calmness might come from his disappointing Olympic discus final, where he finished last. He seems to have moved past this and is happy he made it to the final with an impressive last throw. "That was an amazing day," he says. "The final didn't go as I wanted, but that's part of sport. I can always return to it." After his Olympic setback, some thought he was affected by the big occasion. Lawrence doesn't comment on this. An NFL player's minimum salary is over $400,000 a year, so the financial benefits are clear. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With his great physical abilities, wouldn't it be better to focus on one sport? "I understand why someone would say that," he responds. "I'm trying to achieve something I've dreamed about since I was a schoolkid. If it doesn't work out, I can go back to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I've made has been well thought out."

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see it was already daylight. Looking out the window, I saw the empty landscape below. The dark shades of brown and green reassured me that, even though it was mid-September, winter hadn't started in Siberia yet. There was no sign of human life, just an endless view of mountains, streams, and forests. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. "Good morning, Robert," he said with a slow Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow traveling to remote areas to sell safety clothing to local mining industries. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I explained that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with a one-way ticket because I planned to return to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he said, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I told him I believed there was a road, though not many people used it anymore. "Alone?" he asked, pointing at me. "No, I will be riding with a friend named Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I nodded. Sergei still looked doubtful and said "Holodna" (cold) while pointing outside. I tried to reassure him with hand gestures that I had a lot of warm clothes, though I didn't mention that I was on a tight budget because my trip was self-funded. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at discounted prices. I wasn't sure they would be good enough, especially my large postman's over-trousers, which I bought for £10. It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of students slumped in their seats, some taking notes without much energy. The lecturer droned on. I was thinking about a dilemma. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." In the row in front of me was Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my messy handwriting, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. "OK," it said. Six years later, I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still learning to manage my classes, the job was fulfilling. It was often challenging, rarely boring, and there were long holidays to chase adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventure bug after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more exciting than teaching: cycling around the world.
