Since our first ride together, Al had been taking on bigger challenges. This round-the-world bike trip was his biggest yet. Sometimes he thought the ride or the road would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him. He was having an extraordinary adventure, finding he could handle each new challenge, even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong those who doubted him. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.

In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns racing through pylons that are 15 to 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it's like to participate. An hour before the flight, I had to sign two forms. The first confirmed I was healthy, and the second required me to empty my pockets because small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I learned I needed to stay oriented by looking at the horizon. The pilot would tell me where to look. I was also told to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down. 

Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety briefing. I was instructed not to touch anything. As we taxied down the runway, I tried not to touch the steering pedals or any switches. My mind was made up: I would not relax and enjoy the flight. This is the challenge of high-speed acrobatic flying. To avoid passing out, you must stay calm and focused. You need to tense and relax at the right times. Panicking is not a good idea. This was not comforting as we started accelerating. Dario, the pilot, and I reached the end of the runway in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes. The plane took off, and we quickly turned right. It was a sudden move, and I felt the air leave my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed up, and took short breaths as I sank into the seat. For a moment, I felt 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out. We turned left and dived, leaving my stomach at 2,000 meters and my lungs pressed against the plane's roof. Seconds later, we were 10 meters off the ground, heading for a small gap between two pylons. They passed at 400 km per hour, but my excitement was cut short by a sharp right turn. We hadn't even started the acrobatics yet.

For two minutes, I was allowed to fly the plane. My hand shook so much that the plane shook too—it was that responsive. Then Dario said something, and I asked him to repeat it. Instead of replying, he did a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. "Are you okay?" he asked. "Yup," I replied. "Have you had enough?" "No," I lied. Then he did a loop, flying the plane in a full circle. I know many people would find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters. However, I thought it was too much. At the top of the loop, flying upside down, I heard a small voice saying, "Relax, relax, look up." I looked up and saw some fields. The flight lasted 10 minutes. It was "soft" compared to what the pilots experience during races. To prove the point, Dario ate sandwiches right after we landed. I didn't eat for hours, and that night I dreamed of doing loops over and over.

Doug Allan is a cameraman who films wild animals in cold places. If you've ever seen amazing footage of polar bears in a nature documentary, it was probably filmed by him. He says his ideal temperature is -18C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first passion, and it taught him how to survive in cold environments. His big opportunity came when a TV crew arrived in Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. 'I ended up taking the crew to different places, and after 48 hours I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, underwater.' He is now a top cameraman and has worked on many major TV wildlife series. 'I started at a good time. When I began, hardly anyone had been to the Antarctic. There were people who specialized in coral, elephants, chimpanzees. I just became the cold guy. It was like all these amazing scenes were just waiting to be filmed.' The camera and communication technology was very basic when he started 35 years ago. 'It is certainly easier to film today. Back then, if you filmed something, you had to remember it. Today, with digital technology, you can film a lot and look at it immediately. You used to have to think about what shots you needed next, and what you had missed. You filmed less. Film was very expensive. Today you can have too much material.' 'My value is my field experience in cold conditions. I have a feel for it. I have spent so much time on sea ice it now feels like crossing the street. I do get cold toes but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, no diseases or mosquitoes.' Wildlife filming, Allan says, is full of great successes, but also failures and embarrassments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes. Unfortunately, he could not identify which birds they were. When Allan recently got permission to film sequences for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, he did not expect an easy task. It is a world of polar bears and is strictly off-limits to all but the most fearless or foolish. Usually -32C in April, the wind is harsh and carrying cameras in the deep snow is very difficult. After walking five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow slopes for 23 days, however, Allan had seen just one mother bear and her cub. By day 24, though, he says, he was living in bear world, at bear speed, with bear senses. 'We find a new hole and wait. We shuffle, hop, bend, stretch and run to stay warm. Five hours of watching and then with no warning at all I catch a glimpse so brief that I almost miss it. But the camera’s locked on the hole on full zoom and my eye’s very quickly on the viewfinder. Nothing for a couple of seconds and then an unmistakable black nose. Nose becomes muzzle, grows bigger to become full head and in less than a minute she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She’s looking at me but she’s not bothered. I’ve just pulled out of a close-up thinking this can’t get much better … when she sets off on a long slide down the slope. I’d swear it’s partly in sheer pleasure,’ he recounts, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. ‘Clearly it’s their first view of the world … It’s show time on the slopes and we have front-row seats.’ Now Allan would like to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and experience the impact of it first hand. He says he would be able to make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting extra supplies. This meant he had to swim in freezing waters and deal with frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole too. Now, he is back in the Arctic, preparing for an even more challenging expedition. Explorers are confident and determined people, and Pen is no exception. This time, however, the stakes are higher. Pen and two colleagues will embark on a three-month, 1,000-kilometer journey to the North Pole to measure the ice's thickness and density. No one has done this before, and the results will be crucial for scientists. This will provide the clearest picture yet of how global warming is affecting the polar ice. 

Pen was trained for this kind of work. As a child, he was looked after by a woman who had worked for the famous explorer Scott of the Antarctic. She toughened him up by sending him out into the Scottish mountains during blizzards with minimal clothing. His father also loved icy adventures, and Pen developed exceptional physical endurance. Pen is married to Mary, a horsewoman who says he has a "spine of steel" and shares his love for the outdoors. She helps run his polar guide business and worries more about him when he's at home, saying, "He's in more danger driving along the A303 because I know that in his head he's somewhere in the Arctic." For fun, Mary once raced against him in a mountain event where riders on horseback compete against runners. Mary and her horse finished an hour ahead of Pen. 

Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. "It's much harder to be away from them this time," he admits. "They were one and five when I last went, and I made a mistake in how I said goodbye. I told my son, 'You're the man of the house now, look after your mum and your sister.' He took it seriously, but it was too much pressure for him. It was well-intentioned but unfair." Because of this, Pen plans to have little contact with his family while in the Arctic. "If you call them, you remind them how far away you are." He is spending his last days before leaving preparing his equipment carefully. "Out on the ice, you can't fix things or do anything complicated," he says. Joining him will be Ann Daniels, a top polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer. They will have a support team of six flying in supplies. 

Being part of a team is more stressful for someone like Pen, and he has other concerns too. "I'm turning 47 on Thursday. I've done less training than I would like." Why? "Organizational tasks always seem more urgent. So I'm almost afraid of what I'm going to ask of myself." Pen believes his mission reconnects exploration with the quest for knowledge that inspired past explorers. "Reaching the North Pole was a personal goal," he admits, "and not very useful to anyone outside the polar adventure community. This time, scientists will benefit from the data, and we're trying to engage as many people as possible in what's happening in the Arctic Ocean. This is important work, and only we can do it," he says. "Our skills, which seemed odd and unnecessary, are now very relevant. Suddenly, we're useful to society again."

I took a year off and wondered what to do next. Being an Olympian is amazing, and I had opportunities to write, work on TV, and speak at schools and businesses. While these activities were great, I missed having a competitive challenge. I wanted to stay fit in case I decided to compete in the Olympics again, so I started running marathons and doing triathlons. But there was still Ben Fogle's invitation in my mind: "Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?" I love rowing and missed the feeling of the boat gliding through the water, but I wasn't ready to train every day. I talked to some rowing friends about the race, but no one was interested. I knew if I joined, I would want to win, and I wasn't sure if Ben was the best partner for that. However, the idea of being an underdog with no pressure was appealing. 

I contacted Ben, who was already planning to do the race and had managed to gather the entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We discussed the remaining costs, which were high, with the boat and equipment alone costing £70,000. We thought we had a good chance, but it would require effort to secure everything. Besides the race expenses, I also had to consider the loss of income from being away. Speaking at business conferences is a good way to earn money as a retired athlete, but I find it hard to talk about past achievements without a new goal. Joining the race meant I would have something new to talk about: rowing across the Atlantic.

Planning this adventure taught me to appreciate the simpler life of a full-time athlete. Preparing for the Olympics was tough, but straightforward, with set training programs and support from doctors and dieticians. I was worried about how people would react to me racing with a TV presenter, thinking it might seem like I just wanted to be on TV. But during our preparations, those concerns faded. The Atlantic Rowing Race is more about mental strength than just rowing skills. Ben had done the tough Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and lived on a deserted island. However, he couldn't row well. I was surprised by his lack of natural rowing ability, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I could have been more patient, but I needed to be honest about the improvements he needed. I should have expected his level when I agreed to race with him.

Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle, in the far north of Finland. At 26, I felt restless and dreamed of the cold, open landscapes of the Arctic, maybe as a reaction to the noisy and crowded life in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to hire me as a husky dog handler for the busy winter season. From December to February, they take tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, lasting from an hour to five days. They started with six dogs, which quickly grew to over 100. Recently, they took over a second property called the 'wilderness farm', which they described as a beautiful but basic place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They said I could join the team for three months if I understood what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical.’ I started packing right away.

November 6, London On my flight, I try to memorize the names of over 100 huskies, but I feel distracted and nervous. I put the list down and look out the window instead. People say that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, like a wave of blooming flowers and leaves. But I feel like I’m seeing the opposite, with winter moving south and the rivers freezing.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus ride north is everything I hoped for. We drive through endless dark forests of thin conifers covered in snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer pass. I arrive at the farm after dark and am immediately given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. 'Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?’ Anna asks. It’s a rhetorical question. I follow the barking, which becomes a loud noise as I reach the dog sheds. Three people are running back and forth, harnessing the huskies to sleds. The dogs are almost hysterical with excitement, eager to start. I can barely introduce myself, and the others are too busy to talk. I stand on the side and pet one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestures at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fall into the nearest sled. A command is given, and we take off into the dark, with only a head torch for light.

November 15, Hetta It doesn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but first, I face tough questions about what I can contribute. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asks. I’m unsure. Am I? More questions reveal that I’m not very useful: I’ve never driven a snowmobile, haven’t done woodwork since school, and have never used an axe. 'Do you have a driving licence?’ someone finally asks. I nod, relieved. The basics of dog-sledding are easy to learn: lean into corners, use both feet on the brake to stop, and never let go of the handlebar. But everything else is complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs are hard in freezing temperatures. A bowl of water freezes solid while you watch, so we make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head is full of instructions, and my muscles ache from dragging heavy sleds and being pulled by excited huskies. But I feel triumphant. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I email friends. 'In the snow.’

On that day, when Radcliffe crossed the finish line, the press gathered to understand her amazing run. Her time was so good that it would qualify her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists were curious about a natural treatment she used, emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had recommended. Radcliffe used it to heal after a training accident where she ran into a bike. Radcliffe says the achievement didn't really sink in at the time. Looking back, she realizes it was a big deal, but she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day. Her team had a motto: no limits.

During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Her physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, was also there. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried if she could keep up the fast pace, fearing she might drop out. Hartmann was upset by this, though he admitted that anyone who didn't know how fit she was might think it was risky to start so fast.

With 800 meters left, Radcliffe realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she ran the last part in less than three minutes. She had run 41 kilometers very fast but still managed to sprint the last distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run quicker than that." The race director, Dave Bedford, said he didn't think anyone would come close to that time soon, but Radcliffe thought, "I'm going to come back and do it next year." Unfortunately, that didn't happen.

After the race, people wondered how an athlete with such an awkward style could beat the graceful East African runners. Hartmann had spent weeks with Radcliffe, giving her daily sessions to help with the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could take that level of pain. She would wear me down because I had to go so deep into her muscles that I had to ice my thumbs afterward."

Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no greeting or offer of tea. Radcliffe was ready for a two-hour session. She pushed Hartmann to give his best, which made her so good. During that time, Hartmann spent so much time with Radcliffe that his other athletes became resentful.

Can Radcliffe explain why no one has come close to her record? "Not really. I trained really hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought it might happen with Mary Keitany (two-time London marathon winner). Maybe it's because people are racing each other more than racing themselves." What does she mean? "That mental way of never easing up, even when you've won the race, probably pushed me to it because I never thought, 'I can relax now.' It was always: 'keep pushing as hard as you can.'"

Radcliffe didn't know it then, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She would never run as fast again. However, she left a lasting legacy, inspiring many women to take up long-distance running.

When my first cookery show, "In Search of Perfection," was released, I was unsure how viewers and the press would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food 'revolution' happening in Britain. I believed our show added something new to this movement, but I was still worried. Would people like a cooking show that included not just techniques but also history, nostalgia, and science? I watched the first episode with mixed feelings of joy and fear. I needn't have worried. The show's success led to many other exciting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project feels like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called "Perfection," each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was often very physical, involving travel with passports and suitcases. "In Search of Total Perfection" is the latest in the series, where you travel the world to meet extraordinary artisans, like a man dedicated to making the best golden pasta. These people have spent years pursuing their own ideas of perfection. Perfection is subjective. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was difficult, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorites were left out. I imagined people asking, "Where's steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?" However, after a long meeting, the TV team and I created a list that had something for everyone. This confirmed my belief that everyone has their own idea of perfection, based on personal emotions, memories, and surroundings. Despite the book's title, I never claimed the recipes were 'definitive.' But I thought that by using my technical skills and scientific knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could identify what made these dishes special. The dictionary defines 'perfection' as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation. Trying ideas and refining them until they are unique. The TV series allowed me to explore foods, people, and places I had never encountered in any restaurant. I was excited about this, as well as exploring memory and nostalgia in food, because that's how I started in this business. Searching for the best ingredients took me around the world. Some of my adventures included being taken to a canning factory that processed the wrong type of tomato and visiting a dairy farm with standards so low we had to stop filming. Refining each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow and using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken breasts in a hospital scanning machine, and nearly burning my house down trying to get the oven hot enough for a proper Neapolitan-style pizza.

We were still a few hours away from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, swerved off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and looked under the hood. He stood there for a while, looking at the engine with his hands in his pockets, pretending to know what he was doing. Finally, he admitted, "Actually, I have no idea what I'm doing," and he and Mum started laughing. Bea was worried and said, "We can't stay here forever." The field was vast, with just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. I agreed with Bea because it was always safest to be on her side. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John walk away to find someone who knew about cars. Mum lay down on the grass and asked me to tell a story. Bea lay next to her, and I started telling them about how I heard two birds talking the day before we left London. I told them about the things the birds discussed, like breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and a fight over a worm. Bea said, "That's silly, no one understands bird language." My eyes stung, and I said, "I do," but I didn't sound convincing. "Liar," she said, and I felt embarrassed. I wondered how I could be lying if I remembered everything. I asked Mum, but she had fallen asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped push the van to a hotel. Bea didn't want to get out, but the boys didn't mind and waved at her through the window. We followed John into a café near where the van was parked. "It's a hotel," John whispered, "It might be expensive." Mum said, "We'll just have some tea," and we sat on the terrace. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot and said, "It's like syrup." We stayed at the café all day while John tried to fix the engine. "It's a miracle it got us this far," he said as it got dark. Mum made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It was nice to sleep on ground that wasn't moving. "I'll have to get us towed into Marrakech," John said. Later, we were in a truck watching our van being towed with John driving it. Bea didn't want to move at first, so John carried her into the truck. She sat in the front with the driver. I wondered how we would get home since our van needed to be towed everywhere. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I fell asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom, talking to two other pianists who were playing at the Prague Classical Music Festival. Unlike Lucy, they were not competing. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city, but Lucy didn't catch her name clearly over the noise. It was something like Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke English well enough to discuss the music they were playing, their recent travels, and their future plans. 

Lucy mentioned, "I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer," which sounded impressive. However, she didn't really want to go to the Tanglewood festival, just like she hadn't wanted to do many of the activities that filled her schedule. These included concerts and competitions that took her around the world, causing her to miss so much school that she wasn't officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she studied with tutors from the University of San Francisco. She hadn't even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists in her age group from around the world. Out of thousands of applicants, she was chosen. Her dad celebrated by buying her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant, and her little brother Gus dreamed of attending the festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The thing was, Lucy hadn't applied herself; her mother had filled out the form and sent in the CD. "I didn't want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in," her mom had said. Lucy thought it was more like her mom didn't want to give her the chance to say no. At that time, Lucy believed that causing trouble was the worst thing to do, so she didn't even think about trying to back out.

The guy from Tokyo leaned forward, surprised. "Tanglewood?" he asked. "Yeah," Lucy replied. "How old are you?" "Fifteen." He exchanged a look with Liesel/Louisa, who said, "Wow." Lucy hadn't meant to show off. It was hard to know when sharing her achievements was just fitting in or bragging. "It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're trying..." Liesel/Louisa excused herself, looking across the room as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked, "Have you ever been to Japan?" He had long, shaggy hair, like many male musicians, to show they were rebel music nerds. "Once. When I was, like, eight," Lucy replied. He was about to say something when Lucy's grandfather appeared. "Lucy, let me introduce you to someone," he said, taking her arm and leading her away. "And don't get too friendly with the competition." "They're not the competition," Lucy said. "Everyone is the competition," her grandfather replied.

He took her around the room, introducing her to people he thought were important. Lucy smiled and nodded a lot, only catching about half of what was said. In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather said, "You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are." Lucy liked that part—being somebody. Even if it meant some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention she got. Being a concert pianist didn't earn her any special respect from the kids she used to go to school with. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't know or care that she could play a Rachmaninov allegro perfectly. But in places like this, she knew she mattered.

"It's not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world," said Dad. He's hard to argue with, so I decided to see what experts say about it. It's quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of identity, and are learning important digital skills. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says social networking is a key part of modern childhood. Teenagers don't just use media for tasks like buying tickets or checking emails like adults do; they live in it. It's not about whether it's good or bad, but how you use it.

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did at our age? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it's like the modern version of hanging out at a youth club, where today's parents used to share jokes and gossip. It helps teenagers develop their identity away from their parents and learn to deal with teenage issues and interact with peers.

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says adolescence is a time to ask, "Who am I?" Social networking can help you find your self-identity by sharing your favorite music or sports and seeing different perspectives. Research shows that active social networkers are less self-centered than those who don't use social media. He also says that social media can be helpful if you're shy, as online communication can be more comfortable than face-to-face interactions.

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can help quiet people with specific interests connect with others who share those interests. For example, if you're one of only a few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel isolated. But finding a social networking group with similar interests can make you feel more connected.

Pauline White, a digital education expert, says teenagers who find new interests online and create their own content are really using social networks well. She thinks social networking is becoming a creative force, with teenagers making videos, podcasts, and blogs about their interests. Photo-sharing sites are changing creativity by allowing photographers to network, learn, and share images. This can improve employability and be beneficial in the workplace. Every business uses social media to sell and increase brand awareness, so understanding how it works is important. For example, if you create a product and have 1,000 friends on social networks, they could be potential customers. Linking these networks can build your customer base.

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they enter the workforce, agrees Matthews. Many sites offer opportunities to collaborate and share content, which is a valuable 21st-century skill and important for being employable in a digital age."

When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, a long road trip across nine western states in the US and a Canadian province might not be the first idea that comes to mind. However, my parents had a different plan for our summer vacation this year. My dad decided to organize what many teenagers would consider a nightmare: a big family bonding trip. "Not enough people do this anymore," my parents kept saying before the trip, while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, "There must be good reasons for that!"

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and clothes for all kinds of weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. With barely enough space left in the car, we started our "Family Great American Road Trip." As we left our comfortable home for smaller accommodations over the next five thousand miles, I wasn't the only one wondering what we were getting into.

We headed west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had our share of adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under some of the darkest, star-filled skies in the country, but only after almost being blown off the highway by a dust storm. We quickly learned that on the road, cattle have the right-of-way!

The next day, we were up at dawn and on the move again. I noticed a pattern forming. The desert turned into mountains. The days started to blend together, but each adventure was unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and moved on to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly tourist town gave us a hint of what was to come later in our journey. As we climbed to our next destination, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best left to Jeep drivers. Everywhere we stopped, we saw a mix of ancient and modern. Dodging construction traffic became normal. We laughed as we posed by the big "CLOSED" signs at the Four Corners Monument.

We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. "Bear jams," where traffic stops to let a bear cross, were common, and our own close encounter with a bear and a worried park ranger gave us unforgettable memories. As we continued, life back home seemed far away, and even the old hotel we stayed in, with its creaky floors and no internet or cell phone service, couldn't dampen our spirits. In exchange, I got to see some of the most beautiful views ever.

After watching a rainstorm from our cozy hotel in Canada, we headed back south. My parents were right. You don't need to go to an exotic foreign place to find something amazing. It was bittersweet to be home again, but at least I hadn't fought with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our crazy journey to look through and remember. For me, the best memories were the unplanned, spontaneous moments.

Rose Frost, a sixteen-year-old girl, was moving to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Her family was splitting up for two years because her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, was going with him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy was finishing her last year of school and would live under the care of the college Head. She was happy to have the best room at the college, which included a kitchen and study area, plus free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would still keep an eye on Amy.

Rose was going to her grandmother's house. She only had vague holiday memories of Daisy and had never met her grandfather. Although Rose's parents were not thrilled about the idea, Daisy insisted it was no trouble and was excited to reconnect with her granddaughter. Rose didn't fully understand why her parents had issues with Daisy, but there had been a disagreement in the past, leading to summers spent away from her. Rose's last memory of Daisy was when she was ten, and it was a happy one.

Dahlia mentioned that living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and good at bringing people together. Rose could expect dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon. This made Rose smile because Daisy was not a typical frail grandmother. She seemed to attend more social events than the Queen of England.

Before moving, Dahlia and Rose had a talk. Rose was mature and knew about healthy living. She wanted independence, like playing loud music, inviting friends over, or going out without always asking for permission. She didn't want to be nagged about homework or staying out late. Daisy understood this. Dahlia gave Rose a new touch-screen phone for emergencies, which made Rose very happy. They agreed to trust each other: Daisy would trust Rose to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If there were any issues, they would discuss them.

Rose was not a rebellious child. Her school friends were similar, so her school reports and exam results were always good. This helped her case. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, make new friends, and basically start over. It was her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. She knew this would be her last move as she was starting her final two years of school. For Rose, it was a new chapter in her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first to suggest she might write a novel. She thought writing a book was a big achievement because it seemed challenging, and she wasn't sure what other teenagers were doing, like competing in the Olympics. When she turned 13, she decided to give it a try. Now, the novel she started back then is about to be published. She recently told her former teacher, who was surprised because she thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40. Charlotte couldn't understand why she should wait to do something she might be good at.

It's a winter afternoon at Charlotte's publisher's office. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old about her book, I was still surprised to see a teenager there. The book is impressive: the story is confident and full of action. Nothing about it, except the age of the main character, suggests it was written by a teenager. A public relations representative is with us in case Charlotte needs support, but she doesn't. Charlotte is confident, intelligent, and steady, without being overconfident.

Charlotte admits she is young and doesn't have all the answers. When I ask her about the complex moral issues in her book, she says, "I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don't have many life lessons to share," she laughs. "I don't think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I'm not particularly wise either. I just wanted to explore the theme of taking responsibility."

She has a theory about how teenagers are portrayed in books. She believes there are three types: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who lacks social skills. Reading about these types frustrated her. "What if you're basically fine? There aren't many stories about characters who aren't inadequate in some way. Some writers unintentionally suggest that teenagers can't know who they are because they lack experience, which can hurt their self-confidence."

Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy writers, but they almost discouraged her from writing. "Books by my favorite fantasy writers explore deep psychological and life issues. I wondered if I needed to do the same to write a good book and if I was capable of it." However, she praises a book called How Not to Write a Novel. "It says if the reader can guess what's going to happen, the suspense is probably gone."

Some might think Charlotte's parents, both journalists, helped her get published. Her father's connection in publishing did help her book get read initially. She admits she's lucky because getting a first novel read is tough, no matter the author's age. "Every aspiring writer needs support and a lucky break, but after that, you're on your own. Writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don't take things for granted," Charlotte concludes.

Text: "‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then David, who had some experience in freestyle ski-jumping and wanted to show he knew what he was doing, went first. He skied down the slope towards the jump, hit the ramp fast, and flew into the air with his arms flailing. Even we could see something was wrong. We held our breath. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly told us, ‘speed is unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle skiing. On past skiing holidays, I enjoyed practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I didn’t know how, and I feared being laughed at if I tried to join the skateboarders with their baggy trousers and special language. Then my parents decided on a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a big indoor facility near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students would jump, try new tricks, and land in foam pits – not a realistic start for what awaited us on the slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan assured us. ‘Before places like this, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat section behind the jump before the slope steepens again for the landing. Land in the zone and you keep moving forward, reducing impact. Land on the flat and you stop suddenly, which is painful. That’s why speed is important. At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore my brain and race towards the jump. My legs would almost go backward as I neared the launch point, so I landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt shorter. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I’d hate being indoors, looking at the snowy peaks outside, but bouncing on the trampolines was addictive. Some drills copied ski-jumping moves, others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body is doing as you spin in the air. Gareth gave us feedback. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off, then found myself in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more setbacks before I finally landed properly. Gareth was as happy as I was, and for a moment I felt proud of achieving such a difficult goal. But that didn’t last. On the final run of the day, I kept my speed as I approached the jump, became airborne, and landed correctly. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer on my feet."

Imagine you're on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and your nails dig into the safety harness. The ride stops suddenly, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs upwards. There's a pause, then a sudden drop, and you feel your stomach lift. You speed forward, turn sharply left, and go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you scream from deep inside. But you chose this experience, just like millions of others who visit theme parks every year. 

It's interesting that amusement parks, with their thrilling rides, are such a big industry. To create the excitement and escape that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers and designers working behind the scenes. Being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a child's dream job, but it's actually very challenging. Designers must find the right mix of fun and fear while keeping passengers safe. They also need to add new features to keep people coming back. 

Many people think rollercoasters have become more intense over time, but most of the techniques used today were invented by John Miller, a US designer, in the early 20th century. Back then, rollercoasters were more extreme, but now designers are limited by the track designs from specialist manufacturers.

I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer,' said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts, from the Royal Academy of Engineering, explained that it's about quickly switching between different forces so people feel thrilled but safe. It's a fine line between excitement and discomfort.

To create an amazing ride, teams must build a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, and combine it with new features like the tallest ride or the most twists. However, Professor Walker said that in the end, experience and trial-and-error are key. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed that designers need to love thrills to understand what passengers want and to test rides before they open to the public.

I asked if new technology, like virtual reality, will change rollercoaster design. Walker said not to expect too much. Virtual reality can add something extra, like a nice paint job on an old coaster, but the physical ride experience will remain the most important part for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already accomplished a lot as a choreographer, creating pieces for many theatres and dance companies. She also still dances occasionally. I wonder why she fits both activities into her busy schedule. She explains, "Dancing again reminds me of what it's like to be in the studio, taking orders from demanding choreographers, and how tense and frustrating that can be. Choreographers can forget what it's like to rehearse all day." As a choreographer, she enjoys teaching and working with young students. "New dancers are often open to exploring new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want success but don't fully know their strengths and weaknesses yet. This means they accept even harsh criticism. They might challenge me sometimes, but I welcome their honest feedback."

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her work. "There might be music I'm not fond of, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don't respond well to a certain composer's music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can't just choose a new piece. Ideally, I'd like to be more experimental and switch to different pieces, which would help when rehearsals get tough. But now, I'm always working on big productions where the music is already set by the composer and can't be changed."

Miranda doesn't want to be tied to one institution. "I think it's important to keep meeting new people. But I have to remember that each theatre and school I work with has different methods and styles. So I need to adapt my work each time, instead of doing the same thing everywhere. This helps me avoid becoming too fixed in my ways."

We talk about a recent documentary on professional ballet dancers and choreographers. "There have been glamorous documentaries before that were misleading," says Miranda. "This one tries to show what life in a dance company is really like. There was a scene where a young dancer gets endless corrections, and I recognized that. She knows she's not getting it right but can't make her body do what's needed. It's hard to watch but not staged for the cameras. The public often underestimates the work and dedication involved in ballet."

I'm curious about what makes a great ballet or dance production for Miranda. "It's when everything the company has invested in – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – all come together. Perfection might be too much to ask for, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can make up for a few wrong artistic choices. I've been in productions where the dance steps are great, but something about the costumes or props is distracting. That's disappointing."

Miranda has done a wide range of work, so I ask how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? "People want to label you, and I don't understand that. There's also a trend to focus on a narrow area of expertise. I don't follow that, though maybe one day I'll be known for one thing. For now, I want to broaden my horizons."

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can watch everything on TV. I agreed that TV shows amazing things, but why stay at home when there's so much to experience outside? That conversation inspired my unusual four-day trip and a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of an old sofa, which became the main feature of the film. I attached three wheels and some cables to it and used old seatbelts to secure it over my shoulders. I put my luggage on the seats and slept on the sofa each night, even spending one night on the beach. Several friends joined me along the way, helping to pull the sofa and motivating me to continue. I've been on many walking trips in recent years, but this was completely different. It was the longest distance I've ever walked, and it was on main roads, so I could stop at roadside cafés and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino, instead of having the wind blow away my sandwiches while sitting on a rock. I often had to tell people, "No, I'm not doing it for charity, and I'm not training for a marathon." When someone at work asks about my weekend, I'd rather talk about dragging a sofa 100 miles across southern England than discuss the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I was excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually traveled with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be a good idea. At the Greek port, the man seemed curious when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained I wouldn't be alone for long; I’d be joining ten others to swim around the tiny islands. Although he still looked puzzled, he let me on board with a smile. Our group had exchanged emails before we left, but there was little time to chat before our first group swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would be with us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, then it was time for our first proper 1.5 km swim, and I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but never long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group—not where I wanted to be. I watched faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, though, and was happy when I finally did it on my own. The following days had a routine: jumping in, reaching a comfortable speed, and stopping to admire the scenery. As the swims got longer, so did my speed and enjoyment of completing them. There seemed little need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come again next year.

Being a flight attendant isn't easy, but it's a great job for someone young like me. Since I started, I've traveled all over, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have lots of free time, and life is never dull. As a child, I went to a boarding school abroad and often flew alone. I felt lonely, so I would ask flight attendants if I could help serve meals, and some let me. This memory stayed with me when I wanted to leave my banking job and find a new path. At the interview, there were many young people, and lots of them were accepted. They were often well-qualified and changing careers, like me. I practiced what to say before the interview, focusing on my strengths and work experience, not just my love for travel, and I got the job! I recommend this job to anyone because there are many benefits, but free flights aren't the main one. Airline staff work very hard, and there's a saying: "no-one's finished till everyone's finished." It's like a big family; even if we don't see each other often, we're still close. When I'm not working, I don't have to bring work home. And if I deal with difficult passengers, which doesn't happen often, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won't see them again.

At the summer camp where I work, I love watching the children succeed at things they didn't think they could do. Most of them already know how to swim and play table tennis before they arrive, but rock climbing is new for many. Some kids feel nervous, but with some encouragement, they try it and eventually reach the top. This makes them feel really good. 

At the start of the week, some children miss home. Surprisingly, it's not the youngest ones who feel this way the most, but those aged ten to thirteen. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can call home after lunch. Then, if they ask again after dinner, we say it's a bit late and suggest they call the next day. Most kids are fine after a couple of days, and by the end of the week, they thank us for the great time they had.

It's not just the children who feel lonely; sometimes parents call a lot to check on their child, which isn't really necessary. Often, the child is busy playing games or doing activities, so we ask the parents to call back later. We also often see a certain type of child who comes dressed in expensive new clothes. These children usually argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but they soon understand why it's necessary.

"Rock the Planet" is a musical show where the actors also need to be excellent musicians. It started in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won the 'Best Musical' award four times. However, using an all-British cast was challenging because the UK has stricter rules on how many shows young actors can perform each week compared to the USA. This meant they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have already won their first 'Best Musical' award. The London theatre is larger than the one in the USA, but it has been full every night, with people eager to hear the songs that were first popular in America.

I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, "It's amazing that I get paid to play, especially on a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar." He explained how busy the young actors are, saying, "We have regular school lessons at the theatre every day. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends." When asked about his friends' opinions on the show, he said, "My whole class came to see it! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, which made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it's expensive for them."

When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found an extra one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called "Days," which I didn't know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I was proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie's talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was relieved the show's director wasn't there to hear my mistakes!

Although the young actors were already musicians and some played several instruments, none had been in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together because they were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year and is definitely worth seeing.
